headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone. Thank you for holding and welcome to the Sysco Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And at this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn it over to Mr. Neil Russell, Vice Pres
componenttext: Good day, everyone. Thank you for holding and welcome to the Sysco Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And at this time, for opening remarks and introduction, I'd like to turn it over to Mr. Neil Russell, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Ken Spitler, our Vice Chairman, President and Chi
componenttext: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's Second Quarter Fiscal 2010 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Ken Spitler, our Vice Chairman, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin, please note that statements made in the course of this presentation that states the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or projections of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ in a material manner from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings, including but not limited to risk factors contained in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 27, 2009, and in the company's press release issued earlier this morning.Please understand that all comparisons given during the call refer to changes between the second quarter of fiscal 2010 and the second quarter of fiscal 2009, unless otherwise noted. Also, all comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted.  With that out the way, I'll turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil and good morning, everyone. The second quarter of fiscal 2010, fiscal reported net earnings of $268 million and earnings per share of $0.45, which is up 12.5% compared to the prior year. Sales trend improved throughout the quarter with the
componenttext: Thank you, Neil and good morning, everyone. The second quarter of fiscal 2010, fiscal reported net earnings of $268 million and earnings per share of $0.45, which is up 12.5% compared to the prior year. Sales trend improved throughout the quarter with the year-over-year rate of decline slowing to only 3%, a result largely driven by deflation. Not withstanding the challenging economic conditions, operating margin improved due in part to the favorable impact of COLI as well as excellent cost control throughout the organization. Ken will discuss this in more detail in a [indiscernible].Despite these challenging times, we remain steadfast in our commitment to helping our customers achieve their objectives. We are executing well and reinvesting in our business. Challenging times that historically provided opportunities for Sysco to further differentiate ourselves in the marketplace. Because our customers increasingly look to us for support and business solutions. As the industry leader, we have an unsurpassed ability to leverage our size and scale to benefit our customers. Our financial results for the quarter reflect a disciplined operational execution and excellent customer service that operating companies deliver each and everyday. While encouraged by our financial and operating performance today, we remained committed to continuous improvement and consistently look for opportunities to gain additional efficiencies in this competitive industry. For example, our business transformation project remains on track with the objectives discussed at our Investor Day in December. We expect the improvements driven by this multi-year project will allow us to grow sales, reduce operating costs and more effectively utilize data in our decision making.Now I'll turn things over to Ken. So that he can provide further detail on this and other operational improvements and how we performed in the second quarter.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. I'd like to start by thanking our operating companies for their hard work during the quarter. These results reflect their dedication to our customers and to helping our business succeed in challenging times. Our sales during the quarter were
componenttext: Thanks, Bill. I'd like to start by thanking our operating companies for their hard work during the quarter. These results reflect their dedication to our customers and to helping our business succeed in challenging times. Our sales during the quarter were impacted by deflation of 3.5%, which is measured as the estimated change in the cost of products we buy. Deflation from dairy and beef products had the largest impact, with the balance spread across several categories. On a year-over-year basis, deflation pressures appear to be moderating from the highs we saw early in the quarter.Our operating margin improved to 5.2% in the second quarter while COLI contributed to this improvement, we also significantly reduced payroll expenses and improved productivity in all aspects of our business. We have continued to manage headcount in a manner consistent with the sales environment throughout the entire organization. Our headcount is down 4% year-over-year and 10% over two years. As we improve productivity throughout the company. Operationally, we continue to focus on productivity, which is evident in many of our key operating metrics on a year-over-year basis. But the progress our operating companies have made is even more clear on a two-year basis. For example, in our U.S. Broadline Companies, our diesel gallon usage is about flat with last year's second quarter, but is down more than 10% compared to the second quarter of 2008. Cases per trip increased 3% year-over-year and 4% versus two years ago. Warehouse cases per man hour improved 8% year-over-year and 15% versus two years ago. And we improved our error frequency per cases shipped from an error rate of one out of 1,229 in the second quarter of 2008 to an error rate of one out of 1,799 this quarter. Capital expenditures for the quarter totaled $138 million. Looking ahead, we still expect capital spending for the full year to be in the range of $600 million to $650 million as we continue to invest in our business. This spending includes maintenance items, such as ongoing fleet replacement and facility repairs, as well as growth items such as expansions of our current facilities, potential fold outs and technology. Technology spend includes capital related to our business transformation project. Now I'll turn it over to Chris for a discussion of our finance results for the quarter.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ken. As previously discussed for the second quarter of fiscal 2010, sales were down 3% and estimated deflation was 3.5%. As Ken just mentioned, deflation appears to be moderating from highs we saw earlier in the quarter. Sales were also impacte
componenttext: Thank you, Ken. As previously discussed for the second quarter of fiscal 2010, sales were down 3% and estimated deflation was 3.5%. As Ken just mentioned, deflation appears to be moderating from highs we saw earlier in the quarter. Sales were also impacted by foreign exchange rates which increased sales by 1.2% and the impact of acquisitions which increased sales by 0.6%. While case volume remains negative early in the quarter, it turned positive towards the end of the period. Operating margin in the second quarter improved to 5.2% from 4.6% last year, a 60 basis point improvement. In addition, operating costs were lower in second quarter by $96 million.Ken walked through the main drivers earlier, and I'd like to review the numbers in a little more detail now. The decline in operating cost is primarily due to a $37 million benefit from the year-over-year change in value related to the performance of COLI and a $25 million decline in payroll expense. Operating expenses also improved by $29 million due to lower fuel expenses. However, deal surcharges which are reflected in gross margins were also lower during the period offsetting most of the benefit from lower fuel expense.Net earnings for the second quarter increased 12.9% to $268 million. Similarly, EPS for the quarter increased 12.5% to $0.45 per share. The $0.45 per share includes a $0.01 favorable impact related to an increase in the cash surrender value of COLI compared to $0.40 in the prior year, which included a $0.05 negative impact from COLI.Turning to our brief update on our business transformation initiative, you'll recall that at our Investor Day in December, we shared with you our expectation that the incremental impact of this project would decrease diluted EPS in fiscal 2010 by an estimated $0.05 per share. The project remains on track and our expectations have not changed.Cash flow from operations for the first half of the fiscal year was $144 million compared to $562 million in the prior year period. Cash flow from operations was impacted by IRS settlement payments which totaled $422 million in the first of the year. Additionally, cash flow in the first of the last year was impacted by the timing of certain other tax payments. Last year in the second quarter, we were allowed to defer approximately $280 million in tax payments until the third quarter, which was the benefit allowed the Houston area companies in the wake of hurricane Ike. As you would expect this year, we were not afforded the same deferral and the net effect causes our tax payments this year to appear significantly greater than last.In closing, I'd like to thank all our Associates for their hard work during the second quarter and for your interest in Sysco.  With that, operator, we'll take some questions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] First up in the roster, we have John Heinbockel with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] First up in the roster, we have John Heinbockel with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: What's been the trend this quarter, last quarter in average drop size?

componenttext: In the drop size, it's declining slightly, John.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: Obviously, deflation is weighing on that, do you think it's not down as much as deflation because you're seeing some weaker guys drop out and that's raising the average?

componenttext: I know about the weaker guys, part of it, but I think it is pretty much deflation.

componenttext: It might be down as much as the rate of deflation you're seeing?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I think our guys are doing a good job. Our folks are doing a good job managing the pieces given there's still a lot of pressure in the marketplace, obviously.
componenttext: I think our guys are doing a good job. Our folks are doing a good job managing the pieces given there's still a lot of pressure in the marketplace, obviously.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: What do you think when you think about incremental profit margin on something like that, as you go from 3% deflation to zero or a little bit positive? The incremental margin on that has got to be fairly high. If you look at what that might be, it's going
componenttext: What do you think when you think about incremental profit margin on something like that, as you go from 3% deflation to zero or a little bit positive? The incremental margin on that has got to be fairly high. If you look at what that might be, it's going to be double-digit, I would imagine and maybe even higher than that.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: John, to be honest with you, we really don't look at it like that. What we look at is more along lines of your first question. The key economic metric for us is gross profit dollars per stop. And as long as we can manage that even, through these difficult
componenttext: John, to be honest with you, we really don't look at it like that. What we look at is more along lines of your first question. The key economic metric for us is gross profit dollars per stop. And as long as we can manage that even, through these difficult times when the penetration was awesome and pieces were down, if we can somehow compete to minimize that lots of pieces. And obviously, price our products appropriately. That's what we do and generally that works, that usually ends up with good results for us.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, ERP costs, or business transformation costs, what would that -- did you have that first half of the year, then we go [ph] back in the second half?
componenttext: Secondly, ERP costs, or business transformation costs, what would that -- did you have that first half of the year, then we go [ph] back in the second half?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll preview a little of what you'll see in the 10-Q. As we said in December, the total costs of the project is $900 million. We expected the total spend in 2010 or we do expect now to be somewhere between $250 million and $275 million. The first half, we
componenttext: I'll preview a little of what you'll see in the 10-Q. As we said in December, the total costs of the project is $900 million. We expected the total spend in 2010 or we do expect now to be somewhere between $250 million and $275 million. The first half, we spent approximately 1/3 of that. So the rest will be in the second half of the year. The capital portion of that, $250 million to $275 million is estimated to be about $160 million to $175 million. So the incremental impact from business transformation, we expect to be $40 million to $50 million, which would be a reduction in operating income this year. That's our nickel a share that we previewed in December.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And would the OpEx part of that also be 1/3, 2/3 split?
componenttext: And would the OpEx part of that also be 1/3, 2/3 split?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: It's roughly correct, yes.
componenttext: It's roughly correct, yes.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, what is the environment right now? I mentioned it hasn't change much since December. But the environment acquisition wise, is there much difference domestic versus international?
componenttext: And then finally, what is the environment right now? I mentioned it hasn't change much since December. But the environment acquisition wise, is there much difference domestic versus international?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: The focus is more domestic right now, John. I would say to you, we certainly are continuing to try develop relationships where that make sense. I would say to a point that the environment is not that different, I would say also our environment continues t
componenttext: The focus is more domestic right now, John. I would say to you, we certainly are continuing to try develop relationships where that make sense. I would say to a point that the environment is not that different, I would say also our environment continues to be very proactive. We're looking at as much as we can, we're not waiting for the calls to come in. I think it's fair you could characterize this environment, where if you don't need to sell your business right now, you'll probably not going to be overly interested in doing that.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: But the problem is more quality of asset as opposed to price. The price was the problem in the past.
componenttext: But the problem is more quality of asset as opposed to price. The price was the problem in the past.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at that, it all comes together once you talk to people. But I think right now, folks, they got earnings pressure that's not necessarily a great way to start a negotiation in terms of applying them all. And maybe there's just an element that ever
componenttext: If I look at that, it all comes together once you talk to people. But I think right now, folks, they got earnings pressure that's not necessarily a great way to start a negotiation in terms of applying them all. And maybe there's just an element that everyone is so focused on running their business right now, that they don't really look at it that way. But I think it will pick up. We've been saying that for awhile. We have been disappointed that we haven't seen more activity. But I can tell you internally, we're tidying up our process and making sure that we're exploring things that make sense.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Next up, we have a question from JPMorgan's John Ivankoe.
componenttext: Next up, we have a question from JPMorgan's John Ivankoe.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just illuminate the comment that your case volumes had stabilized towards the end of the second quarter. On a casual dining, at least on a reported basis, you have stayed very weak. I mean the traffic down, approaching 5%. QSR
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just illuminate the comment that your case volumes had stabilized towards the end of the second quarter. On a casual dining, at least on a reported basis, you have stayed very weak. I mean the traffic down, approaching 5%. QSR, from what we understand got worse in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. So I mean if you could just give us a little bit of a look through in terms of what type of accounts that you have, restaurants or other business that's doing really well from you? And if you could also put that comment in terms of how much of the stabilization and sales trends is just from the fact that you're taking much more share per account.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the question is how did the quarter look for us in terms of increasing our cases through our operation. And I guess, sequentially, it got better as we went along to the point of December was relative to the rest of the environment, pretty good mon
componenttext: I think the question is how did the quarter look for us in terms of increasing our cases through our operation. And I guess, sequentially, it got better as we went along to the point of December was relative to the rest of the environment, pretty good month what we saw, nice little bump in cases. Hence, probably the rest of the question has how does it look in January. We're still seeing positive cases. But it's declined from December numbers. So we're still optimistic because it generally does that anyway. So it's following kind of a standard pattern, if you will, but the good news is, it's still positive. As far as -- there's still closures going on in the Restaurant business, you're still seeing certain parts of the industry that you guys know about are declining in case sales. Part of our business to, is not related necessarily to the Restaurant business, which is Healthcare, is no pun intended, quite healthy and growing. And of course, our Institutional business in Schools on those kind of things have maintained their sales. So a little part is, yes, I think we are taking share. It's still one of those difficult questions to answer for you because it's hard to know, it's hard to sort out declining cases and certain customer basis and where you're gaining shares in other cases. So it's really hard to sort out. It's just at the end of the day, the real measurement that we've got to use is are we increasing our cases? And the answer to that is yes. Did I get them all?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you did. If you would mind, can you even look through a little bit more, especially on your Broadline's business. I mean is there geography, specifically, that's doing very well? And is there a type of account within Broadline perhaps in the Restaura
componenttext: Yes, you did. If you would mind, can you even look through a little bit more, especially on your Broadline's business. I mean is there geography, specifically, that's doing very well? And is there a type of account within Broadline perhaps in the Restaurant that doing particularly well, especially relative, for example, the first quarter?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, we still continue to have rough go in the Midwest and in the Florida area and somewhat on the Southern West Coast. So that's kind of remains the same. The South and Southwest is doing pretty good. The Northeast is holding its own. Northwest seems to
componenttext: Sure, we still continue to have rough go in the Midwest and in the Florida area and somewhat on the Southern West Coast. So that's kind of remains the same. The South and Southwest is doing pretty good. The Northeast is holding its own. Northwest seems to be holding its own. Within the category of Restaurants, it seems to us the family-style restaurant, the restaurant that is a value driven is doing pretty well right now. And the top end still suffer. Meaning $100 a meal in that kind of places are still trailing pretty badly. Did that help?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's move on to our next question, that's Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Let's move on to our next question, that's Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Just curious, if you look at your headcount reduction about 4%, how much of that you think will hold when we start coming out of things and volume has really start picking up? It seems to me like you're going to add up back some bodies when the case volum
componenttext: Just curious, if you look at your headcount reduction about 4%, how much of that you think will hold when we start coming out of things and volume has really start picking up? It seems to me like you're going to add up back some bodies when the case volume starts picking up?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: We are already starting to add back bodies in terms of the sales force. Sequentially, we're up - I was looking at that number it's about 75 to 100. We've added sequentially over the last few months. So yes, we've already started adding back salespeople be
componenttext: We are already starting to add back bodies in terms of the sales force. Sequentially, we're up - I was looking at that number it's about 75 to 100. We've added sequentially over the last few months. So yes, we've already started adding back salespeople because we think that the environment is right for us to start continuing leverage to grow sales. And then, it becomes a matter of we have improved some productivity. We're still improving productivity. It's not going to be a one-for-one bring back. Although it does have a lot to have cases. To tell you that I have that exactly in mind, but I can tell you this that we will be a leaner organization as the sales start to grow because as we've been forced by this environment, we've gotten a lot more productive. When you have an error rate in our business of one in 1,800 and then just in the last some '08 to '09 to '10, we've gone from 695 cases to 701 to 722. Those are all the kind of things that you don't backup on, you don't need to backup on, continuous improvement, your cases per man hour. Those are big numbers to us. And we're going to get improvement on those just because the economy gets better, those numbers don't go down. So we've really been forced, in some ways, forced to do to get better faster. We still got a lot of initiatives out there that we've talked about in December to really improve our productivity. So long story short there, and I rambled a little bit I'm sorry but, these improvements are sticking.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And if you could just give us a little bit of snapshot. You talked a little bit about share and which segments are doing better or worse and parts of the country are doing better or worse -- but how is the price competition out there right now and what do
componenttext: And if you could just give us a little bit of snapshot. You talked a little bit about share and which segments are doing better or worse and parts of the country are doing better or worse -- but how is the price competition out there right now and what do you see in that regard?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: It's tough. We have very aggressive competitors on the price front. That's not our first rodeo there of course so we're used to being the market leader. So we're used to staving off price attacks. It's been a lot more frequent now and of course, the custo
componenttext: It's tough. We have very aggressive competitors on the price front. That's not our first rodeo there of course so we're used to being the market leader. So we're used to staving off price attacks. It's been a lot more frequent now and of course, the customer base gets a little more receptive. So we've had to be cautiously defensive about that. But, yes there's definitely an uptick to it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And you generally been matching where you've been meeting competition?
componenttext: And you generally been matching where you've been meeting competition?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say we always matched the price. That's a waterfall that you don't want to go over but we've found ways to hang on to our business without destroying our margins, which is no mean trick.
componenttext: I wouldn't say we always matched the price. That's a waterfall that you don't want to go over but we've found ways to hang on to our business without destroying our margins, which is no mean trick.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Question now from Ajay Jain at Havilland Securities.
componenttext: Question now from Ajay Jain at Havilland Securities.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to go back to the question about the improved case volume trends. If I understood correctly, it sounds like volume stabilized further in November and December, relative to what you presented at the Analyst Day. So I'm just wondering, is t
componenttext: So I just wanted to go back to the question about the improved case volume trends. If I understood correctly, it sounds like volume stabilized further in November and December, relative to what you presented at the Analyst Day. So I'm just wondering, is there's any rethrough [ph] for the Indiana RDC based on what you're seeing right now? Are you close to a decision there?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're pretty close. What we'd like you to see is -- as you know, our business, Ajay, we make this quarter in March and if we continue to see good-paced growth through March that we'll feel very comfortable about going forward. We couldn't put a shove
componenttext: Yes, we're pretty close. What we'd like you to see is -- as you know, our business, Ajay, we make this quarter in March and if we continue to see good-paced growth through March that we'll feel very comfortable about going forward. We couldn't put a shovel in the ground in Indiana right now anyway. So I will feel comfortable after we see the March numbers and the quarter numbers. I feel pretty comfortable that we're going to go forward with this. But we'd like to see those numbers stabilize. We need positive cases to make the RDC go around and we won't build that till we see it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ajay, it's Bill. I just want to clarify something in terms of how you caveated that question. I would say to you that the volume trends we've seen since the Analyst Day are very consistent with what we talked about at the Analyst Day. We were startin
componenttext: Hey, Ajay, it's Bill. I just want to clarify something in terms of how you caveated that question. I would say to you that the volume trends we've seen since the Analyst Day are very consistent with what we talked about at the Analyst Day. We were starting to see an uptick in late November, December and it's been very mild and modest and that's how it's been. But to Ken's point, this a unique quarter and until we get into March, it's really hard to draw any conclusions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the improvement in comparisons for bad debt expense, my question is whether that improvement is a function of the operating environment just getting better or if there's something specific that you're seeing with your customers in terms o
componenttext: And then just on the improvement in comparisons for bad debt expense, my question is whether that improvement is a function of the operating environment just getting better or if there's something specific that you're seeing with your customers in terms of their credit quality?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: We managed the credit the same way we've managed it for 35 years. So we've just been very careful and cautious. I can't really tell you whether it's -- I think we have good customer quality at Sysco and that's one of the things that you're seeing in our w
componenttext: We managed the credit the same way we've managed it for 35 years. So we've just been very careful and cautious. I can't really tell you whether it's -- I think we have good customer quality at Sysco and that's one of the things that you're seeing in our writeoffs, it's that our customers are managing their business is pretty well too.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think if you look at last year, you'll see the third quarter. We really took a pretty substantial hit by our standards. So we'll be going up against that this quarter. So again, our folks do a good job managing credit. We've been fortunate. Part of
componenttext: And I think if you look at last year, you'll see the third quarter. We really took a pretty substantial hit by our standards. So we'll be going up against that this quarter. So again, our folks do a good job managing credit. We've been fortunate. Part of that is customer quality. And we haven't had big hits and hopefully that will continue. But I would still say business is [ph]  fragile out there.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, just on the headcount reduction. I just want to clarify one thing. It sounded like you're hiring more sales people, so I'm just trying to reconcile the additional headcount in marketing associates that Ken talked about with the decrease in payrol
componenttext: Finally, just on the headcount reduction. I just want to clarify one thing. It sounded like you're hiring more sales people, so I'm just trying to reconcile the additional headcount in marketing associates that Ken talked about with the decrease in payroll cost that you just reported. Should we infer that you're adding more customer contact personnel but lowering headcount in other areas of the company?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily, no. It's sequential, first of all. We're still down from like in over a year ago but we're not -- it's strictly marketing associates that we're adding.
componenttext: Not necessarily, no. It's sequential, first of all. We're still down from like in over a year ago but we're not -- it's strictly marketing associates that we're adding.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: So I'm still trying to reconcile the Delta there. So if your payroll costs are down, year-over-year, you're saying that's all marketing associate-driven?
componenttext: So I'm still trying to reconcile the Delta there. So if your payroll costs are down, year-over-year, you're saying that's all marketing associate-driven?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: No, what we're saying is we're down year over year in headcount, including in sales and down in payroll. And that what Ken was saying earlier is that, as we're managing the business going forward, sequentially, we're beginning to have sales people. But we
componenttext: No, what we're saying is we're down year over year in headcount, including in sales and down in payroll. And that what Ken was saying earlier is that, as we're managing the business going forward, sequentially, we're beginning to have sales people. But we're still down in salespeople year-over-year. So that's consistent with the payroll number.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Can we talk a little bit first just about fuel. And I know that you had less fuel cost but also less fuel surcharge. But fuel prices are starting to go up again? Can you talk a little bit about how you think that plays out for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Can we talk a little bit first just about fuel. And I know that you had less fuel cost but also less fuel surcharge. But fuel prices are starting to go up again? Can you talk a little bit about how you think that plays out for the rest of the year?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: We, of course, are very concerned about how it plays out the rest of the year. And everything that we're seeing, reading, being coached on, tells us that what we're seeing about, seeing as a barrel price right now, is about what we can expect for the rest
componenttext: We, of course, are very concerned about how it plays out the rest of the year. And everything that we're seeing, reading, being coached on, tells us that what we're seeing about, seeing as a barrel price right now, is about what we can expect for the rest of the year. So we're not looking for any big increases.

componenttext: About 40%. So we protected this as much as we think we need to. So again, we're not diesel experts, we're just trying a year-over-year comparison flat. Again, who knows? So our prediction is, and from our experts that we rely on, that next year is going to be relatively flat.

componenttext: They could at a certain level. They're always up there. We don't see that being triggered at this level.

I'm just wondering whether the gross margin ended up being pretty much in line with what you had expected for the quarter? You did have a pretty good gross margin performance last quarter but were about flat this quarter. Was there a surprise in that to you are was that in line with your expectation?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: I'd say its in line with our expectation given Ken's characterization of the market, which is it's very extremely competitive out there. It remains that way. And I think we'll be fighting margins here for a while.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And then my final question is to just go back to what Chris was saying about the business transformation process. I think I'm a little thick this morning. The numbers that, Chris, you talked about, the 900 million, that's both CapEx and operating expenses
componenttext: And then my final question is to just go back to what Chris was saying about the business transformation process. I think I'm a little thick this morning. The numbers that, Chris, you talked about, the 900 million, that's both CapEx and operating expenses. And then you gave, specific numbers and I was just trying to make sure the numbers you have 250 to 275 in the first half. Is that a combination of CapEx and operating expenses?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Let me go back for it just to make sure we're clear. If you recall back in December, we said 900 million was the total cost of project, both capital and operating expense. We also shared a bar chart that said that we expected 2010 to be about $275 mil
componenttext: No. Let me go back for it just to make sure we're clear. If you recall back in December, we said 900 million was the total cost of project, both capital and operating expense. We also shared a bar chart that said that we expected 2010 to be about $275 million. We are now saying, and you'll see this in the Q, we expect that to be a range of 250 million to 275 million for the year. So that's bot operating expense and capital. The capital portion of that, we expect to be 160 million to 175 million. That's the full year number, right? And then we gave the break out of which we spend about a third of that today and roughly a third both on the capital side and the operating expense side. So the remainder will be the in the back half of the year.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: Moving on now to Andrew Wolf and BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the last -- the expenses with the SAP and the transformation project. So 100 million for you all is roughly about $0.10 a share. Does that mean you have $0.05 in there last year or -- I'm balancing here. I'm also having a thickness issue with your
componenttext: Just on the last -- the expenses with the SAP and the transformation project. So 100 million for you all is roughly about $0.10 a share. Does that mean you have $0.05 in there last year or -- I'm balancing here. I'm also having a thickness issue with your numbers.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: No, again not a thickness. It's a new topic, we haven't talked about it a lot about. So we know that there's going to be some education process here. We used the term incremental not to mean year-over-year. Again we discussed in December, we put a lot of
componenttext: No, again not a thickness. It's a new topic, we haven't talked about it a lot about. So we know that there's going to be some education process here. We used the term incremental not to mean year-over-year. Again we discussed in December, we put a lot of folks that were already here at Sysco on to this project. I think 312 was the number that we talked about in December. So those people were in our run rates, our expense run rates last year. Those folks are now working on the project. So when we talk about $900 million project, that's the total cost, including those people. But those people aren't incremental expense. So when we talk about year-over-year, that was the number I gave earlier, we expect to expense year-over-year to about $40 million to $50 million additional.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. So there's already -- let's use 100 as a round number. You're already spending 50 to 60.
componenttext: Okay, got it. So there's already -- let's use 100 as a round number. You're already spending 50 to 60.

componenttext: So we're now looking at all the outside folks that we've had to hire to bring it to manage the project.

componenttext: Primarily the COLI and the tax settlement, if you're looking at the first half. Tax settlement obviously affected the tax rate to the tune of I think 300 basis points, 320 basis points. And then COLI, which is not deductible for income tax purposes, affected it both this year and the last year different directions.

And it looks like they're doing an orderly liquidation and just sort of Sysco's coming in and servicing those customers. Is this --

componenttext: We were the white knight here. There was an order and they shut down at best.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: You guys had referenced that. As an industry leader, you sort of have a certain responsibility and I understand that. But what I really want to know is, I assume in the long run getting these customers is probably a good thing. Is this kind of liquidation
componenttext: You guys had referenced that. As an industry leader, you sort of have a certain responsibility and I understand that. But what I really want to know is, I assume in the long run getting these customers is probably a good thing. Is this kind of liquidation something you think is sort of a one-off or is this something if the environment doesn't pick up, that we might see some more of?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're going to see some are of that, Andy. They just run up to the post here and it's over. They do care about their employees. They want a little help with their inventory. We could do all of that for them and are glad to do it. It's good fo
componenttext: Yes, I think we're going to see some are of that, Andy. They just run up to the post here and it's over. They do care about their employees. They want a little help with their inventory. We could do all of that for them and are glad to do it. It's good for us. It's good for them.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: So on consolidation, it kind of looks like if things don't get better, this could happen. And If things get better, Sysco might be able to hit the bids on some improving businesses. Is that somewhat realistic way to look at how consolidation could unfold?

componenttext: I'm not sure I understand that question, Andy?

componenttext: Maybe the environment gets better and these reluctant sellers, their EBITDA goes up, it might be easier to buy them?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean we certainly hope so. And like I say, our antenna's up and we're doing what we can do. But they've got to get to a point where they want to sell the business and negotiate in a reasonable way. And as Ken said, these types of deals you're talki
componenttext: Yes, I mean we certainly hope so. And like I say, our antenna's up and we're doing what we can do. But they've got to get to a point where they want to sell the business and negotiate in a reasonable way. And as Ken said, these types of deals you're talking about right now are, sometimes they just ran out of fumes at the finish line. It's not always protracted discussions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly on inflation, has it switched to inflation yet? And overall, and can you give a little bit of a category flavor?
componenttext: Lastly on inflation, has it switched to inflation yet? And overall, and can you give a little bit of a category flavor?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: It hasn't switched. It continues to moderate. And the categories would be, in terms of the delation, the categories are the ones that are driving it. Up to this point, we've been to dairy, beef, that type of thing. Going forward, some of this, what we'd l
componenttext: It hasn't switched. It continues to moderate. And the categories would be, in terms of the delation, the categories are the ones that are driving it. Up to this point, we've been to dairy, beef, that type of thing. Going forward, some of this, what we'd like a lot of these numbers, you're going to wrap some numbers here pretty soon. So we would expect the dairy deflation pressure to ease. Beef is probably a harder one to call. In the supply side, there's not a whole [ph] supply, but the demand continues to be weak. And that seems to be keeping those prices under pressure. So we'll have to see there. So we're hoping they can see a continuation of the moderations, if you will, and at some point, see some mild inflation. But it's hard to call for its timing.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not sure of the timing. But from our merchandising folks, when I'm talking to the manufacturers, there is a feeling and a prediction of inflation to come in those significantly bigger areas of beef, pork, poultry, dairy. So that would be good n
componenttext: Yes, we're not sure of the timing. But from our merchandising folks, when I'm talking to the manufacturers, there is a feeling and a prediction of inflation to come in those significantly bigger areas of beef, pork, poultry, dairy. So that would be good news for us. I hope that's right.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, when you start talking of inflation especially in this environment, the best scenario for us is two to three points. We certainly wouldn't be fans of returning what we were a year and a half ago, where it's six and eight points, because our custome
componenttext: Again, when you start talking of inflation especially in this environment, the best scenario for us is two to three points. We certainly wouldn't be fans of returning what we were a year and a half ago, where it's six and eight points, because our customers have enough challenges as it is without that.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go now to Greg Badishkanian at Citi.

componenttextpreview: I think our customers are getting smarter on the discounting. Where it works in some form or fashion, sure they are. There's been some other people out there that have tried some things but they haven't gotten the return for it.
componenttext: I think our customers are getting smarter on the discounting. Where it works in some form or fashion, sure they are. There's been some other people out there that have tried some things but they haven't gotten the return for it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you also spoke about productivity, which you guys have done an amazing job over the last two years or so. Obviously, you're hiring people a few more people back, but what's the real opportunity there to cut cost so that you can improve efficienci
componenttext: And then you also spoke about productivity, which you guys have done an amazing job over the last two years or so. Obviously, you're hiring people a few more people back, but what's the real opportunity there to cut cost so that you can improve efficiencies further in 2010 calendar versus what you did in calendar 2009? Or have you kind of, basically, taken up all the kind of low-hanging fruit?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, none of it's low-hanging. But it all takes a lot of work and we still got a plenty of room out there to improve. And we've got 10 initiatives prior to the installation of our first SAP that we want to finish that, will give us another pretty signifi
componenttext: Well, none of it's low-hanging. But it all takes a lot of work and we still got a plenty of room out there to improve. And we've got 10 initiatives prior to the installation of our first SAP that we want to finish that, will give us another pretty significant boost in our productivity. And just to give you an example, we're going to continue to run on our SWMS platform, which is our operating system in the warehouse as opposed to SAP. So we have an initiative out there that is a best practices initiative. That we will -- it's all kind of, I call it switch-driven. But doing certain things, certain way, in all of our operating companies within three months are going to go best practices. And we'll have that finalized in July. We should see a really nice uptick then across the board productivity. But again, we have 10 of those out there. That's just one of them. So to say that we're all done, that is not true. We still got lots of room. We still got lots of improvement. There are some definitive spots where we run up against. Physically, we'll probably be able to get to about 750, 760 cases per truck and then you'll run out of room. But there's lots of other productivity measures that we continue to increase on and continue to have room to do.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I mean I just, real quick -- I think when you read the Q, you're going to see tone in this issue is just what Ken said. We certainly see room for improvement, there's a lot going on with that. The rate of improvement is not going to be what you've s
componenttext: Greg, I mean I just, real quick -- I think when you read the Q, you're going to see tone in this issue is just what Ken said. We certainly see room for improvement, there's a lot going on with that. The rate of improvement is not going to be what you've seen over the last 12 to 18 months. Unless we get some case growth.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Nice to see the improvement in volume and overall trends. So keep up the good...
componenttext: Nice to see the improvement in volume and overall trends. So keep up the good...

headline: Sysco Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-01-2010
componenttextpreview: Keep in mind too that most of these are case-driven and we've got cases going down. You get some case improvement, you get some improvement just by the nature of the math. So I mean we got headwinds all over the place and still improving.
componenttext: Keep in mind too that most of these are case-driven and we've got cases going down. You get some case improvement, you get some improvement just by the nature of the math. So I mean we got headwinds all over the place and still improving.
