headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we put that in there on purpose, or at least I did, from the standpoint that, like I said, we're pleased. We've seen strength in the economy here for a while. We think we're beginning to see the consumer participate. And as a result, we're seeing so
componenttext: Well, we put that in there on purpose, or at least I did, from the standpoint that, like I said, we're pleased. We've seen strength in the economy here for a while. We think we're beginning to see the consumer participate. And as a result, we're seeing some growth with our customers, and obviously in our top line. I wanted to temper that a little bit with just the reality that it's still very competitive out there. And I wouldn't expect that to change a whole lot in the near term.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Neil Currie with UBS.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Neil Currie with UBS.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you could maybe give us some insights on your outlook for deflation, and any trends you're seeing in April so far, whether you're actually starting to move into inflation now?
componenttext: I just wondered if you could maybe give us some insights on your outlook for deflation, and any trends you're seeing in April so far, whether you're actually starting to move into inflation now?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our track record on projecting inflation and deflation isn't really strong. But what we're trying to say, Neil, to you in our comments this morning is we believe that the deflation has subsided to the point where, as we say, in March, it was pretty flat.
componenttext: Our track record on projecting inflation and deflation isn't really strong. But what we're trying to say, Neil, to you in our comments this morning is we believe that the deflation has subsided to the point where, as we say, in March, it was pretty flat. And we don't have a lot of information yet so far this quarter, but it looks like it is starting to pick up modestly. So I think we are back in an overall net inflationary environment, albeit very modest.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of underlying demand, you obviously talked about easy comparisons because it was so tough last year. But I wonder if you could talk to what's going on behind the underlying volume growth that you're seeing right now? How much of it is share growt
componenttext: In terms of underlying demand, you obviously talked about easy comparisons because it was so tough last year. But I wonder if you could talk to what's going on behind the underlying volume growth that you're seeing right now? How much of it is share growth? And how much of is -- how much have you seen a pickup in demand recently?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're clearly seeing a pick in demand, and as I said, we're real pleased to see that. Obviously, it's good for our customers, it's good for our people. The psyches of everyone in this industry is -- it's been difficult for the last year and a half o
componenttext: Well, we're clearly seeing a pick in demand, and as I said, we're real pleased to see that. Obviously, it's good for our customers, it's good for our people. The psyches of everyone in this industry is -- it's been difficult for the last year and a half or two years. So from that standpoint, we're seeing an overall pick up in demand. Yes, we think were still taking share. That's a hard question to answer at a given point in time. But we don't have any reason to believe that we're not continuing to take share. So we're pleased with the year-over-year numbers. I think if you go back two years, we would tell you that we're still a little bit below where we were two years ago. And I think that's consistent with our headcount reductions and that type of thing as well.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, I wonder how fragile or robust you think this recovery is? And if gas prices were to get notably higher over the summer, how would you think that might impact both demand and your opt only onto [ph] (22:31) your customers?
componenttext: And finally, I wonder how fragile or robust you think this recovery is? And if gas prices were to get notably higher over the summer, how would you think that might impact both demand and your opt only onto [ph] (22:31) your customers?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we had fragile in one of our early drafts, Neil. We took it out because we think we've moved past fragile, but we're not quite to robust. So somewheres in between there. I think what we need to see is -- personally, I'm really encouraged that we're
componenttext: Well, we had fragile in one of our early drafts, Neil. We took it out because we think we've moved past fragile, but we're not quite to robust. So somewheres in between there. I think what we need to see is -- personally, I'm really encouraged that we're starting to see the consumer start to participate. That's what we've said all along would be the key for us, is we can see case growth and that allows us to do what we're really good at, which is leveraging that case growth. So that's our best read on that situation right now, I think.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of a little bit on the kind of the food inflation and promotional environment. As you kind of go into an inflationary period, how much does that help you relative to when you look back two quarters ago, you were running, even last quarter, n
componenttext: Just in terms of a little bit on the kind of the food inflation and promotional environment. As you kind of go into an inflationary period, how much does that help you relative to when you look back two quarters ago, you were running, even last quarter, negative low single digit? How much benefit do you get as you get to an inflationary environment?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, that's hard to quantify. What we've consistently said, and for those of us who have been around this business a long time, it does hold up: The preferred environment, we could pick an inflationary environment, it would be one of modest inflation, on
componenttext: Greg, that's hard to quantify. What we've consistently said, and for those of us who have been around this business a long time, it does hold up: The preferred environment, we could pick an inflationary environment, it would be one of modest inflation, one, two, maybe three points inflation, for a couple of reasons. One is, that's a level that typically, our customers have been able to handle over the years with their customers. And two, we can manage that fairly well. So that's the more favorable environment. The environment we were in a year to two years ago where we were looking at 6%, sometimes 8% inflation, that's not good for anyone. It's not good for the customer and it's certainly not good for the industry. And then what we think we're coming out of the deflationary environment would be the least attractive, probably of the three. Although, I have to say we've been real pleased with how our folks have managed through that over the last six to nine months or so, so it'll help us some. But I think the main thing, when you look at our business right now, where we're at right now is we need to see case growth, our customers need to see volume increases. So at relatively low levels of inflation, that shouldn't be a barrier.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: At then in terms of the promotional environment, as you start to see inflation, as you start to see some decent volume growth and that only builds as the consumer gets stronger, do you think that, that's going to abate the promotional environment?
componenttext: At then in terms of the promotional environment, as you start to see inflation, as you start to see some decent volume growth and that only builds as the consumer gets stronger, do you think that, that's going to abate the promotional environment?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it'll affect it. There's always a lot of promotion activity that goes on in our business, both with our customers and we do some, as do our competitors. I would hope that what it results in is a more targeted, more cost effective promotion environ
componenttext: I think it'll affect it. There's always a lot of promotion activity that goes on in our business, both with our customers and we do some, as do our competitors. I would hope that what it results in is a more targeted, more cost effective promotion environment. Whereas, what we were seeing six and 12 months ago is just kind of constant forward [ph] (25:29) type of promotion activity that -- it's not clear that, that really was successful for a lot of people that implemented that. We really didn't approach it that way. We took a more targeted approach.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, I think when you updated us last quarter, you said January was cases were up. But it sounded like barely, and I think, it's sounds like from your tone, February is sort of the same and then March strengthened up. Can you tell us a little about how y
componenttext: Bill, I think when you updated us last quarter, you said January was cases were up. But it sounded like barely, and I think, it's sounds like from your tone, February is sort of the same and then March strengthened up. Can you tell us a little about how you think -- and I'm inferring but I'd like to ask you directly, how April went? Did you see that kind of follow through? And could we expect perhaps an update on the Mother's Day, since May is a big month for the company?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Now you're asking a lot there on Mother's Day. But as far as April goes, Andy, that's when we took fragile out of the early draft. I think we've seen now the month of April, and it's pretty comparable to what we saw in March. So again, we're not out of th
componenttext: Now you're asking a lot there on Mother's Day. But as far as April goes, Andy, that's when we took fragile out of the early draft. I think we've seen now the month of April, and it's pretty comparable to what we saw in March. So again, we're not out of the woods with this recovery yet. But we're seeing two good months in a row, and April is encouraging. We'll see on Mother's Day. The tricky thing on Mother's Day is what I alluded to earlier. That is our biggest week of the year. And it's always an exciting week within the operating companies. But in terms of what that number is, hopefully, it will be up over last year. I think it'll be interesting to see where it is relative to two years ago.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on the SAP update, some of those things sounds like getting some of the benefits perhaps above budget. It sounds like they could be longer lasting than just this fiscal year. Whereas, the accounting may not be, it may just be the way the projects
componenttext: And just on the SAP update, some of those things sounds like getting some of the benefits perhaps above budget. It sounds like they could be longer lasting than just this fiscal year. Whereas, the accounting may not be, it may just be the way the projects rolling out. But should we, perhaps, anticipate some updates to beyond fiscal '10, perhaps when you present your fourth quarter numbers?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you can anticipate updates. Our current intention is when we come out with fourth quarter, we'll give -- and I think, Sysco is traditionally giving guidance on a few items for next year, capital expenditures, et cetera. And we've said that we will tr
componenttext: Yes, you can anticipate updates. Our current intention is when we come out with fourth quarter, we'll give -- and I think, Sysco is traditionally giving guidance on a few items for next year, capital expenditures, et cetera. And we've said that we will try to update you on the business transformation for 2011. We will also be taking a fresh look periodically, we're going through it now, on the entire chart that we presented in December. We may not present that in our fourth quarter update, but we would intend to present that, certainly, at our Investor Day later in the fall, winter. So you can expect updates as we go forward.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, it sounds like it's certainly coming in early yet, but it's being run pretty tightly, and some of the benefits are better than expected. Would we be getting ahead of ourselves if we took something away from that to the positive side?
componenttext: I mean, it sounds like it's certainly coming in early yet, but it's being run pretty tightly, and some of the benefits are better than expected. Would we be getting ahead of ourselves if we took something away from that to the positive side?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll echo what you just said. I think it's being run very, very tightly. I think the team that's running that is doing a good job of cost control. I wouldn't get too euphoric yet about seeing more benefits here. As we described, and we were pretty careful
componenttext: I'll echo what you just said. I think it's being run very, very tightly. I think the team that's running that is doing a good job of cost control. I wouldn't get too euphoric yet about seeing more benefits here. As we described, and we were pretty careful to describe it, so you'll understood it. Some of the benefits we're seeing right now is, we didn't backfill yet some of the positions that we thought we would backfill. That doesn't mean we won't backfill them. Obviously, we don't hire people once we need them. But there's a chance we still will backfill some of those people, and so that benefit would then go away. But we're giving you the best look that we have right now. And that says that for this year, we're not going to spend as much as we thought. But it was important that we noted that we're not changing the overall cost of the project. Eventually, we believe we're going to spend the money and it will be broken down between the capital and the expense fairly similar to what we had anticipated when we described it at Investor Day.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one last question, is a follow-up on the -- now that there's some inflation coming back. As your sales people and your operators are seeing, week-to-week, sequential increases in protein and other categories, dairy, maybe keep produce out of this
componenttext: And just one last question, is a follow-up on the -- now that there's some inflation coming back. As your sales people and your operators are seeing, week-to-week, sequential increases in protein and other categories, dairy, maybe keep produce out of this since it spiked. But sort of some more normal incremental inflation, is the market basically absorbing that, which it normally does? Or are you seeing some sticky pricing and a little gross margin pressure?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: What we've seen, like I said, Andy, it's Bill again, we've done a nice job managing the margins, I think, through this last year or so. But it's been very competitive on the street. I would say, especially right around the first of the calendar year, and
componenttext: What we've seen, like I said, Andy, it's Bill again, we've done a nice job managing the margins, I think, through this last year or so. But it's been very competitive on the street. I would say, especially right around the first of the calendar year, and we've continued to work on margins here over the balance of the quarter and into April. As far as the stickiness, I would say to your point, I mean, most of what we're seeing on the inflationary side is more commodity-driven right now, but it's not radically up. Dairy is up, but dairy has been down for quite a while. So I'd say we're, so far, would been able to pass along most of it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a little bit about your operating expense progression. You just lapped the big cost cuts from last year. The operating environment is getting a little better. I mean, what do you think is a reasonable progression for operating expense growth
componenttext: Wanted to ask a little bit about your operating expense progression. You just lapped the big cost cuts from last year. The operating environment is getting a little better. I mean, what do you think is a reasonable progression for operating expense growth in percentage terms?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Chris is hesitating, so I'll start. I wish I knew the answer to that exactly. But I think what we need to call out here, Mark, is I think we're at an inflection point. So for the last year, year and a half, the way we have been looking at the busine
componenttext: Well, Chris is hesitating, so I'll start. I wish I knew the answer to that exactly. But I think what we need to call out here, Mark, is I think we're at an inflection point. So for the last year, year and a half, the way we have been looking at the business is, how aggressively can we, should we cut relative to the decline in volume. And as you can see, we've been able to manage our headcount pretty much in line with the volume decreases, and that's necessary in this business, given the people and people relate is 70% give or take of our total cost structure. So I think we've said here for the last few months anyway that we've short of continued productivity improvements, which we expect to continue to enjoy. Like I talked about earlier, we've cut a lot, and it's really going to be hard to cut a whole lot more. Now as we go forward, with the premise that we're expecting to see some modest growth, I think you'll see us, and we actually for the first time, I think here in several quarters, we are up year-over-year with our sales headcount, marketing associates and so on. And so we will add there, and we have been adding there over the last six months or so. But I think the other areas, assuming we see a relatively modest pickup in cases, we still have quite a bit of capacity in our facilities and on our trucks continue to leverage. So I think nothing really changes other than the environment here. So you could expect us to continue to try to drive the earnings faster than the top line.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And those changes you've made to the marketing associate headcount, do you think they've had time to kind of have an effect on market share? Or is it still too early?
componenttext: And those changes you've made to the marketing associate headcount, do you think they've had time to kind of have an effect on market share? Or is it still too early?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little early. I mean, the thing to keep in mind is even though the net number may have been flat or down for a period of time, we're always refreshing the pool of sales people. So when we're at our best and things are clicking, there's alwa
componenttext: I think it's a little early. I mean, the thing to keep in mind is even though the net number may have been flat or down for a period of time, we're always refreshing the pool of sales people. So when we're at our best and things are clicking, there's always a percentage of that sales force that's in what you might characterize as a training mode. And so the folks that were coming out last year, they're a little bit better than they were last year, a little more experienced than [indiscernible]  So -- but I would say what we're speaking to here today, that it takes generally, to be honest with you, it takes 18 months to three years for people to fully hit their stride in the sales area.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us an absolute number on how much the volumes had changed? I mean, we're kind of doing back-of-the-envelope math, and we think it's maybe around 1%. Is that about right for the volume gain?
componenttext: Could you give us an absolute number on how much the volumes had changed? I mean, we're kind of doing back-of-the-envelope math, and we think it's maybe around 1%. Is that about right for the volume gain?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, we've never really talked about specific volume increases. For the first time, this release we actually indicated whether they were up or down. One of our goals is to try to get to a point where we're comfortable talking about volume increases, but
componenttext: Mark, we've never really talked about specific volume increases. For the first time, this release we actually indicated whether they were up or down. One of our goals is to try to get to a point where we're comfortable talking about volume increases, but there's some math we've got to play through before we can actually get comfortable releasing that number. There is a number that I know all of you guys get to call the real growth, I guess, which you just take the number that we put out in terms of sales and then you adjust it for the acquisition to ForEx, and the deflation or inflation and you get to a real growth number. I think that's what you were referring to when you got to the 1%. Yes, I mean, I think a lot of you guys do that calculation. You can kind of see the trend in that number. Again, we don't put that in the release because we're advised that it would be non-GAAP and we can't talk about it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just in relation to the $0.03 dilution for ERP. Can you confirm the earnings impact in Q3? And what you're anticipating this quarter?
componenttext: Just in relation to the $0.03 dilution for ERP. Can you confirm the earnings impact in Q3? And what you're anticipating this quarter?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're not really talking about it on a quarter-by-quarter basis, Ajay, and that's kind of what we indicated back at the Investor Day. Our goal is to give you an annual impact from that so that you guys can put it into the models, which I know are impo
componenttext: No, we're not really talking about it on a quarter-by-quarter basis, Ajay, and that's kind of what we indicated back at the Investor Day. Our goal is to give you an annual impact from that so that you guys can put it into the models, which I know are important to you. Trying to do it quarter-by-quarter is going to be very difficult for us to predict in advance because of the significant timing things that occurred during the quarter. So we're not doing that today. In the 10-Q, we do actually talk about ERP expense. Well, I'm not sure if it's broken out ERP expense to-date; it's probably not. But we do indicate we've spent, I believe, 70% of the range that we gave you.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you have any comment, Chris, on the lower interest expense and why it was down a little bit sequentially?
componenttext: And do you have any comment, Chris, on the lower interest expense and why it was down a little bit sequentially?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have swaps, which were not in place at this time last year. I didn't actually go back and look at the effective interest rate between this year and the last year. I'm not sure it's significantly different, so I'm guessing that the majority of that
componenttext: Yes, we have swaps, which were not in place at this time last year. I didn't actually go back and look at the effective interest rate between this year and the last year. I'm not sure it's significantly different, so I'm guessing that the majority of that difference was the swaps.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And I know you guys mentioned that sequentially, the volume trends improved each month in the March quarter, and it sounds like volume trends are still pretty solid through April. So with the improving case volume trends, are you any closer to making a de
componenttext: And I know you guys mentioned that sequentially, the volume trends improved each month in the March quarter, and it sounds like volume trends are still pretty solid through April. So with the improving case volume trends, are you any closer to making a decision for the Indiana RDC because it sounded like a couple months ago, that the only thing holding you back was just a more material improvement in demand, so if you can comment.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ajay, it's Bill. We are, but we're just not quite there yet. And the one other factor -- so the premise of your question, that's exactly right. We were looking to see some meaningful improvement because it's basically the 24-month time period from th
componenttext: Yes, Ajay, it's Bill. We are, but we're just not quite there yet. And the one other factor -- so the premise of your question, that's exactly right. We were looking to see some meaningful improvement because it's basically the 24-month time period from the time you break ground until you're in full ramp on one of these deals. I won't call it complication, but the other factor that centered the equation here is synchronizing the Midwest RDC with our ERP rollout to those companies that are impacted there. So I don't expect us to break ground this year, to be honest with you. But I do expect later in the year to be in a position to be more specific on that. But it's kind of moved off of the volume issue and it's just trying to sync this thing up towards the most efficient relative to how we do the ERP rollout but with our operating companies.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, I think you guys made some changes last year on your bonus structure, at least at the corporate level. So after you factor in the comparisons from last year and the changes in your incentive structure, I'm just wondering how material that imp
componenttext: And finally, I think you guys made some changes last year on your bonus structure, at least at the corporate level. So after you factor in the comparisons from last year and the changes in your incentive structure, I'm just wondering how material that impact could be on bonus accruals for this quarter, because I'm assuming that at the corporate level, the majority of bonuses were still paid out in Q4, is that correct?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, they're paid out at the end of the year. We accrue from throughout the year. We really didn't make any changes last year, Ajay. Two years ago, we made some changes, relatively modest. We went to return on capital as opposed to return on equity
componenttext: Well, yes, they're paid out at the end of the year. We accrue from throughout the year. We really didn't make any changes last year, Ajay. Two years ago, we made some changes, relatively modest. We went to return on capital as opposed to return on equity and that type of thing. But the thing that hasn't changed is it's pretty much driven on improvement, earnings per share improvement over the prior year, and then the other axis on the grid is a three-year trailing average on return on capital. I think the substantive difference this year is we have earnings improvement, so we would expect to pay our bonuses this year, where as last year, we didn't pay them out at the corporate level.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: But is it material enough that you think it's appropriate to call out?
componenttext: But is it material enough that you think it's appropriate to call out?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we did, so...
componenttext: Well, we did, so...

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've called out the year-over-year change. The absolute amount of it now. I mean, we've been accruing for it periodically, and it doesn't rise to the level of materiality, to be honest.
componenttext: Yes, we've called out the year-over-year change. The absolute amount of it now. I mean, we've been accruing for it periodically, and it doesn't rise to the level of materiality, to be honest.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jason Whitmer with Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jason Whitmer with Cleveland Research Company.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: William, you've absorbed a few more responsibilities over the last quarter or so, as Ken is retired, can you talk a little bit about some strategic, some tactical and maybe even some people changes, whether in Houston or in the field that you've been eval
componenttext: William, you've absorbed a few more responsibilities over the last quarter or so, as Ken is retired, can you talk a little bit about some strategic, some tactical and maybe even some people changes, whether in Houston or in the field that you've been evaluating or executing?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd be happy to, Jay. As you had said, it's not really just Ken's retirement, although that's a significant event for us here at Sysco. Steve Smith has also announced his retirement. In conjunction with that, we are making some changes. All these cha
componenttext: Yes, I'd be happy to, Jay. As you had said, it's not really just Ken's retirement, although that's a significant event for us here at Sysco. Steve Smith has also announced his retirement. In conjunction with that, we are making some changes. All these changes are effective with the new fiscal year. So we're in what I would characterize as a transition period right now. We're also in a period where over the last week or two, and in particular, the next six to eight weeks, we're very, very focused on doing our profit plans with all of our operating companies, as well as here at corporate. But essentially, what you'll see going forward is Mike Green will take over responsibility for the U.S. Broadline operating companies. Larry Pulliam will continue to oversee contract sales, our distribution services corporate group, as well as SYGMA and our specialty company. So those two gentlemen will be overseeing the business. Reporting in to Mike will be Scott Sonnemaker and Chuck Staes, who currently report in to Mike; and we've added a third gentleman, Mike Headrick, who will oversee our companies in the South. Mike is a longtime Sysco veteran, a very astute business person, we're excited to have Mike step up here. And then in conjunction with that, we've also identified 11 other folks, as well as what we're doing up in Canada, which I would characterize as more market VPs, and this is all new for us, Jay. If you go back, I don't know, I guess 15 years, I think around the mid-'90s, we went to the Senior VP of Ops structure, which was a first for us. And at that time and for many years after that, most of those folks, generally, we have four regions, they might have 15, maybe as many as 20 companies, which was effective but probably not overly manageable in some ways. As you know, in recent years, last year or two, in particular, we've gone to a more of a POD structure, which I think has been the transition to get us to where we're heading today, which is more what I'm going characterize as a market structure. We're trying to be very customer-centric. And so with this market structure, we're going to have 11-plus Canada folks overseeing markets. They will not be running operating companies. They'll be working very closely with the operating company presidents in their marketplace to drive out our go-to-market strategy, to effectively implement the 212 business transformation work, to enhance what we're doing on the talent management side of the company, to better develop customer relationships that might crossover local lines, as well as to hopefully bring even more effective focus to our acquisition work. So I'm excited about that. It's a new structure, and we'll begin to transition into it here as we go into the new year. In addition to that, we've asked Kent Humphries, who has done a great job running our Canadian business, to pick up expanded responsibilities. And Kent's going to report in to Larry and head up our contract sales effort across the country. And Kent brings, not just a lot of experience, but a lot of, frankly, enthusiasm and energy to that position and tremendous relationships, both within Sysco and with the customer base. In addition to that, Alan Hasty, who currently runs our Cleveland company is going to come down to corporate and work with Bill Day and his group to -- Alan's primary responsibilities will be to work in our BSCC merchandising area. So we have made several moves. There will be some more that I'm sure you'll learn of, which will be more replacing some of the folks that we've promoted, and those will come out as appropriate over the next couple of months. But essentially, to cut through it all, as we go through these changes, we transition through the retirement of Ken and Steve, I just thought it was appropriate to leverage the talent that we do have in a bigger way, and we have a very deep bench in Sysco. We've got a lot of people that are more than capable and want to contribute more, and that's what's behind these changes.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The shared service announcement, that sounds like if you're doing it on a separate facility, being done in Houston a number of times, it looks like you have a big campus to begin with. But a sep [separate] facility, I'm curious how big is corporate now an
componenttext: The shared service announcement, that sounds like if you're doing it on a separate facility, being done in Houston a number of times, it looks like you have a big campus to begin with. But a sep [separate] facility, I'm curious how big is corporate now and how big is the shared services in headcount as you build that from scratch?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to come back to you with the specifics on that. But the difference between the campus that you seeing which, for the record, is two buildings, but it is big and there's plenty of square footage. So hopefully, Jay, there will be an opport
componenttext: Well, we're going to come back to you with the specifics on that. But the difference between the campus that you seeing which, for the record, is two buildings, but it is big and there's plenty of square footage. So hopefully, Jay, there will be an opportunity for us that we'll have some capacity here over time. But the difference in this facility that we're going to be moving into is, it formerly was a call center for another major company, and we think it's best suited for our business going forward. It's quite large, it's several hundred thousand square feet. And I will be able to speak to the numbers and all that, I think, as we get closer to the end of the calendar year.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a housekeeping question on fuel costs. I think it was mentioned that it actually was a benefit in this quarter. If you could remind us or tell us how to think about the next six or 12 months? And the second question, maybe a little bit longer,
componenttext: First, just a housekeeping question on fuel costs. I think it was mentioned that it actually was a benefit in this quarter. If you could remind us or tell us how to think about the next six or 12 months? And the second question, maybe a little bit longer, it's just kind of the overall state of the industry in terms of health of competition, if you think most of the competition has gotten out of the woods and is going to benefit from this improving environment where there might be things that I don't understand and could be even closures or more share loss of the competition, and whether this is the right environment for you to be looking at acquisitions as we begin the upturn?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: John, this is Chris. I'll take the fuel costs one first. Fuel costs, we look at it as a net between the cost of fuel and then surcharges. On a year-over-year basis, we saw a benefit. The guidance that we've given is we expect the fuel costs to be as much
componenttext: John, this is Chris. I'll take the fuel costs one first. Fuel costs, we look at it as a net between the cost of fuel and then surcharges. On a year-over-year basis, we saw a benefit. The guidance that we've given is we expect the fuel costs to be as much as $50 million to $80 million better than last year, and the fuel surcharge to be about $60 million roughly worse than last year. So net-net, depending on where we fall in that first range, we should see a benefit year-over-year, and that's recent guidance. So that's where we thought -- that's where we believe the net fuel charge will end up for the year.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think as far as the competitive side, John, look at the improving climates, good for everyone. I mean, it's good for our customers, it's certainly good for us, and I would expect it's good for our competitors now. I think going forward, we're extremely
componenttext: I think as far as the competitive side, John, look at the improving climates, good for everyone. I mean, it's good for our customers, it's certainly good for us, and I would expect it's good for our competitors now. I think going forward, we're extremely well positioned to grow and to continue to invest in our business. The one interesting thing, as we've talked before with the model for this business is when you're not growing, assuming you can manage your receivables relatively well, you actually don't need a lot of capital unless you're going to expand your business. So when you do grow, that does put some pressure on the working capital. So I think from that standpoint, if we have some competitors out there that are able to grow, then they'll be dealing with that, and I'm sure they'll be able to deal with that. But I don't see a whole lot of change on the competitive environment. On the acquisition angle on that, we keep hoping for angles here. And perhaps, a better environment will help us all come to more realistic terms on valuation. Some of these situations and people will be more motivated to strike some common ground on valuation now that the business is beginning to improve. So I think it could be a good thing.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Bob Cummins with Wellington Shields & Co.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Bob Cummins with Wellington Shields & Co.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It strikes me that this is only the beginning. Obviously, your numbers are up a bit over last year, the top line I mean. But it seems -- as we all know, Americans love to eat out, and the environment, I think, as it's developing, is going to encourage the
componenttext: It strikes me that this is only the beginning. Obviously, your numbers are up a bit over last year, the top line I mean. But it seems -- as we all know, Americans love to eat out, and the environment, I think, as it's developing, is going to encourage them to eat out even more. And obviously, from your point of view as a company, you don't have a lot of bodies to your staff as the business increases, you just load more goods on the truck, which is very profitable business. It seems to me that both top line and bottom line results over, say, the next four quarters or so should continue to gain substantially year-over-year. Am I right in thinking that? You don't have to comment if you don't want to.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and let Chris clean it up here a little bit on the financial side. But I think if you take a purely operational point of view, you're exactly right that with an improved environment out there, our customers should see more traffic, and th
componenttext: Well, I'll start and let Chris clean it up here a little bit on the financial side. But I think if you take a purely operational point of view, you're exactly right that with an improved environment out there, our customers should see more traffic, and that translates into more opportunity for us to grow and to be more efficient. We've done a nice job, Bob. We've done -- we've been able to grow our pieces per mile and all that type of thing, but it's difficult to grow your pieces per stop when your customers' business is often. So certainly, that would be a metric that we would expect to improve. There's no way of knowing on these things. And if you go back and look at the psychology in over last year, two years, we've kind of struck, I think, a reasonable middle ground. We've never said that we thought that the industry was going to just go totally south for an extended period of time. We certainly acknowledge that the last year to two years have been difficult and the industry has declined. I think the reasonable case is it continues to be what we talked about up in New York in December, which is a modest nominal growth for the industry over time, and that would translate to good things for us. There's some below the line things for next year that I think we've called out and that you would need to deal with. And I'll let Chris kind of transition that conversation.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I hate to be the finance guy that throws cold water on anything, especially since you stated it in such a nice way. I agree with everything Bill said in terms of kind of the medium term. Short term, where we're just looking at year-over-year lapse, w
componenttext: Yes, I hate to be the finance guy that throws cold water on anything, especially since you stated it in such a nice way. I agree with everything Bill said in terms of kind of the medium term. Short term, where we're just looking at year-over-year lapse, we've gotten some good benefits this year from COLI, which is not the way you want to make your numbers obviously, but that's just what happened in the market. We certainly would not anticipate that type of benefit occurring every year. We've gotten some benefit this year from fuel. We've gotten some benefit year-over-year from bad debt expense. So some of the things we've talked about in these calls as being year-over-year benefit, of course, we can't count on them having those come back in our favor next year. Next year, it's the year where we just need to have operating performance. And I'll go back to what you said, the signs look good, the trends look good, and we're very hopeful. Bill alluded earlier that we are, this month, the next month, doing all of our profit plan for the operating company and we're rolling all that up to see what we really believe we can accomplish next year. And we're all anxious to see what our operators, to post closest to the customers believe. As we roll that up and then bake it into our one year forecast with all these items, we'll have a better idea of what 2011 looks like.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then my final question is just about back to fuel expense. You do hedge in some fashion a certain percentage of it. Can you talk about how much of it is hedged through the end of the year? I was kind of surprised that you had such a big range on the c
componenttext: And then my final question is just about back to fuel expense. You do hedge in some fashion a certain percentage of it. Can you talk about how much of it is hedged through the end of the year? I was kind of surprised that you had such a big range on the cost, given that you only have one quarter left for the year. So I was wondering, is it less hedged now?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, May-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We do put in place hedges. We essentially hedge a portion of our fuel. When we look at how much to hedge, we factor in the fact that a lot of our contract customers, whether they'd be SYGMA or contract customers, there's already effectively a hedge in tho
componenttext: We do put in place hedges. We essentially hedge a portion of our fuel. When we look at how much to hedge, we factor in the fact that a lot of our contract customers, whether they'd be SYGMA or contract customers, there's already effectively a hedge in those contracts in terms of the fuel surcharge. So we look at what effectively unhedged, and we go out and we put in place hedges on a substantial portion of that. I think the number is roughly 40% of our overall gallon per hedge. We roll those forward month-to-month. And that just means that we keep going out another month, another month and another month as we see the need to do that. So we're never completely hedged in terms of real financial hedges in the marketplace. 40% is roughly the number where we've been at. The guidance number comes from several things. One of which is we just don't know what fuel costs are going to do in the next couple of months, and so the guidance is still reasonably wide.
