headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sysco Announces Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Neil Russell, Vice President of
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sysco Announces Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2010 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Chris Kreidler, our Ch
componenttext:
Thank you, James, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2010 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made on the course of this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information concerning factors that could cause the actual results to differ in a material manner from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings including but not limited to risk factors contained in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 27, 2009, and in the company's press release issued earlier this morning. 
As disclosed in our earnings release this morning, our operating results this year included an extra week of operations due to the timing of the last day of our fiscal year. As a result, the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010 included 14 weeks of operations compared to the fourth quarter last year, which included 13 weeks. And fiscal year 2010 included 53 weeks of operations compared to the prior year, which included 52 weeks. On the call today, we will discuss year-over-year comparisons that include the impact of the extra week of operations. 
However, to provide financial results that are more comparable on a year-over-year basis, certain metrics will be provided, which removed the estimated impact of the extra week. These adjusted metrics are non-GAAP financial measures. You can find a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures on our Investor Relations website at sysco.com. Also, all comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted. Lastly, we ask that you reserve December 2 on your calendars for our Analyst Day in New York. Additional information will be provided in the next couple of weeks. 
With that out of the way, I'll turn the call over to our President and Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin this morning by recognizing our management team and all of our associates for both their commitment and hard work. They kept their full attention in servicing our customers and effectively man
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin this morning by recognizing our management team and all of our associates for both their commitment and hard work. They kept their full attention in servicing our customers and effectively managing expenses throughout a second consecutive challenging year. 
This morning, Sysco reported net earnings of $338 million for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010. We are pleased to see case lines once again increase year-over-year. While we have seen no consistent pattern of improvement on a week-to-week basis, we are encouraged by the fact that we have now experienced positive line comparisons through the past several months. In addition, we experienced food cost inflation as measured by the estimated change in our cost of goods during the fourth quarter for the first time in a year. Specifically, inflation contributed approximately 2.2% of our overall sales growth for the quarter, driven mainly by higher prices in the dairy, meat and produce categories. 
I am particularly pleased with how well our operating companies continue to manage their expenses. Along with supporting the growth of our customers, improving our operational effectiveness remains a key area of focus throughout Sysco. While industry conditions are more favorable than they were a year ago, our marketplace remains highly competitive. This environment has increased pricing pressures, which we have and will continue to work through with our customers. Specifically, we focus our efforts on differentiating our product and service offerings, more effectively utilizing our scale to better integrate our enterprise-wide capabilities and reducing our cost structure over time. We believe that we've been able to take share as a result of these efforts. 
Reflecting on the entire fiscal year, we sold more than $37 billion of product, shipped more than 1.2 billion cases, generated $2 billion of operating income, recognized record earnings of $1.99 per diluted share, produced cash flow from operations of $885 million and distributed $580 million of dividends to our shareholders. 
Turning to our multi-year business transformation initiative for a moment, we currently have more than 300 people dedicated full time to the project. Over the past two years, we have completed much of the design and technology development work and are currently testing systems and processes. The project remains on track, and we currently expect our first operating company to go live early next calendar year. Subsequent rollouts will occur in ways of five to 10 operating companies through the end of 2013. This project is the single most important initiative we have undertaken since the formation of Sysco. As previously communicated, we are investing significant amounts of financial and human capital to better position Sysco for profitable sales growth for years to come. We will continue to provide periodic updates as we move forward with the work. 
On last quarter's call, we discussed the new operational leadership structure we were preparing to put in place. Mike Green is now leading the U.S. Broadline companies, and Larry Pulliam is overseeing contract sales, SYGMA, distribution services and the specialty companies. Additionally, we have recently realigned our U.S. Broadline leadership responsibilities into 11 geographic markets. These changes became effective with the beginning of our new fiscal year. This new structure enhances our go-to-market strategy, allows us to more effectively implement our business transformation project, helps us develop and strengthen customer relationships across over local lines and improves our approach to building a pipeline of acquisitions. In addition, the new organization structure provides a broader platform to further develop our most talented and experienced leaders now and in the future. 
I would like to close my prepared comments this morning in the same manner which I began by thanking our 46,000 associates for their efforts and engagement over the past year. While encouraged by volume trends that continue to be favorable, we recognize that the broader economic climate may remain tenuous for some time. Accordingly, we are committed to aggressively deploying all of Sysco's resources and capabilities moving forward to effectively support our customers and fully realize the opportunities available to us in the $200 billion foodservice industry. Now I'll turn things over to Chris so he can provide additional details on our financial results for the fourth quarter and fiscal year.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. What I'd like to do first this morning is provide a brief summary of the formal GAAP results. These GAAP results include the impact of the extra week of operations that Neil mentioned earlier. That means these
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. What I'd like to do first this morning is provide a brief summary of the formal GAAP results. These GAAP results include the impact of the extra week of operations that Neil mentioned earlier. That means these numbers compare 14 weeks of operations in the fourth quarter of 2010 to 13 weeks in the fourth quarter of 2009, and 53 weeks of operations in fiscal 2010 to 52 weeks in fiscal 2009. 
On a GAAP basis, for the fourth quarter, sales were $10.3 billion, an increase of 13.9% compared to the prior year. And operating income was $584 million, an increase of 8.1% compared to the prior year. Net earnings were $338 million, an increase of 7.1%, and earnings per share were $0.57 compared to $0.53 in the prior year or an increase of 7.5%.  
On a GAAP basis, for the year, sales were $37.2 billion, an increase of 1.1% compared to the prior year. And operating income was $2 billion, an increase of 5.5% compared to the prior year. Net earnings were $1.2 billion, an increase of 11.7%. Earnings per share were $1.99 compared with $1.77 in the prior year or an increase of 12.4%. 
As I mentioned, those year-over-year comparisons on a GAAP basis are not comparable because that extra week of operations in the fourth quarter impacts all the year-over-year comparisons. So what I'd like to do now is discuss our results for the quarter and the year, excluding the impact of that extra week. That means these adjusted numbers compare 13 weeks of operations in the fourth quarter of 2010 to 13 weeks in the fourth quarter of 2009, and 52 weeks of operations in fiscal 2010 to 52 weeks in fiscal 2009. This should give you a better sense for what's going on in our business, and it's the same basis that the management team has been using to analyze our financial results. 
On an adjusted basis for the quarter, sales increased 5.8% compared to the prior year, driven mainly by case volume growth and the impact of food cost inflation, which we estimated to be 2.2% for the period. In addition, changes in foreign exchange rates increased sales by 1.3%. Adjusted operating income was essentially flat in the fourth quarter, increasing only 0.4%. Adjusted operating expenses were higher in the fourth quarter by $76 million. The increase was primarily due to a $30 million charge related to corporate-owned life insurance or COLI, and $29 million in higher incentive compensation expense. 
Bonus accruals were lower last year in the fourth quarter because we did not meet all our 2009 performance objectives. However, based on the financial results announced today, we met certain 2010 performance objectives and have accrued for bonuses accordingly. 
Additionally, gross margin was slightly lower, which we largely attribute to the pricing pressures Bill mentioned earlier. Adjusted net earnings for the fourth quarter were $314 million and were essentially flat compared to the prior year, declining less than $2 million. Adjusted earnings per share were $0.53, including a $0.02 negative impact from COLI. In the prior year period, earnings per share were also $0.53, but included a $0.03 positive impact from COLI. 
Turning to the year-over-year comparison, while sales declined 0.9% for the year on an adjusted basis, it really was a year with two distinctly different halves. The first half of the year was marked by deflationary pressures across most food categories and case volumes that were negative year-over-year. Consequently, sales in the first half were down 5.7%. However, in the second half of the year, deflation moderated and turned inflationary, while case volumes began to increase year-over-year. As a result, sales in the second half of the year increased 4.1%. 
Throughout the year, we managed our cost very aggressively with particular focus on pay-related costs. At the end of the fiscal year, headcount was down 2.2%, demonstrating this progress. This is on top of the 6% reduction achieved in fiscal 2009. Our sales per employee has increased 1.3% this year and 5.7% over the last two years. We continue to implement key benefits from our various operating initiatives, which helped us leverage more of our sales to the bottom line. 
Adjusted operating expenses declined $132 million or 2.6% in fiscal 2010 compared to fiscal 2009. The decrease in operating expenses was primarily the result of more than $70 million reduction in fuel expense, a $65 million favorable change related to COLI and a $40 million decline in bad debt expense. These decreases were partially offset by a $37 million increase in company-sponsored pension expense. As a result, adjusted operating income increased $62 million or 3.3% to $1.9 billion for the fiscal year. Adjusted net earnings for fiscal 2010 were $1.2 billion, an increase of $100 million or 9.5% compared to the prior year. 
Adjusted EPS was $1.95 aided by a $0.05 tax benefit related to the company's IRS settlement announced in the first quarter of fiscal 2010 and a $0.04 favorable impact from COLI. EPS in the prior year period was $1.77, which included a $0.07 negative impact from COLI. 
This is the end of our discussion of the results of operations on a non-GAAP basis. Comments from here forward in the call reflects GAAP amounts. 
Turning to a brief discussion or brief update on our business transformation initiative, the project decreased diluted EPS this fiscal year by approximately $0.02. This result is lower than the $0.03 estimate we provided on our third quarter call, due primarily to timing and our ability to capitalize more costs than anticipated. 
Turning to cash flow, cash flow from operations for the fiscal year was $885 million compared to $1.6 billion in the prior year period. Cash flow from operations in the current period was impacted by IRS settlement payments totaling $528 million and early pension contribution payments for fiscal 2011 totaling $140 million. We have now paid more than half of the total IRS settlement amount, and we'll pay approximately $212 million per year in fiscal 2011 and 2012 to the pave of our normal estimated tax payments. Due to the timing of those tax payments during our fiscal years, there is no cash impact in our first fiscal quarter of either year, $106 million cash outflow in each second quarter period and a $53 million cash flow in each of the third and fourth fiscal quarters. 
Capital expenditures totaled $157 million for the quarter and $595 million for the year, in line with our guidance. Spending for the year included investments in technology, including our business transformation project, fleet replacement, a purchase of a facility for our future shared services operations and the replacement or expansion of facilities in Vancouver, Toronto, Houston, Philadelphia and Plainfield, New Jersey. 
In July, we announced the acquisition of Lincoln Poultry & Egg Co. in an all-cash deal. Lincoln Poultry service more than 800 customers located mainly within the Central United States and generates approximately $200 million in annual revenues. We believe that their high-quality operations and strong customer relationships will be an excellent growth opportunity for Sysco. As discussed previously, we continue to be active in the acquisition market, working to identify opportunities that we believe may be a good fit for us. 
Looking ahead into next year, there are a couple of important items that we want you to keep in mind as you think about fiscal 2011. First, fiscal 2011 will be a 52-week year. The 53-week anomaly we had in fiscal 2010 occurs every six years. So the next year we have this issue again will be in fiscal year 2016. And second, we recognized certain gains during the year to be mindful of: a onetime tax benefit of $29 million in the first quarter of this year related to our IRS settlement, and $22 million in total gains related to COLI that impacted operating income throughout the year. 
In addition, we are also providing a few guidance metrics for the year ahead. We expect capital spending for fiscal 2011 to be in the range of $700 million to $750 million as we continue to invest in our business, including $160 million to $180 million of capital related to our business transformation project. We expect pension expense for the year to be approximately $60 million higher than fiscal 2010. This increase is primarily due to a decrease in the discount rate used to determine pension expense, which is, in turn, driven by the significant decline in long-term interest rates over the last year. Finally, we estimate the net impact of the business transformation project will reduce EPS by $0.06 to $0.09. This range is a bit lower than the projections we provided last December at our Investor Day and is primarily attributable to our ability to capitalize more of the cost of the project. 
In closing, while the business environment in fiscal 2010 was challenging, our Operating Companies did a great job of managing through those challenges with a strong focus on growing cases, reducing costs and improving productivity. That focus has continued into the new year, and we are confident that Sysco is well positioned to successfully address the new challenges and opportunities that we will experience in fiscal 2011. With that, operator, we will now take questions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question today from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question today from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: First question I would like to ask is just if you could talk a little bit more about the competitive environment. You talked about it being a lot of pricing pressures. Could you just maybe elaborate on that a little bit?
componenttext: First question I would like to ask is just if you could talk a little bit more about the competitive environment. You talked about it being a lot of pricing pressures. Could you just maybe elaborate on that a little bit?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Bill. Yes, we've been talking about it really for the better part of the year, I guess. And what we're seeing out there is I think what you're seeing across all the spectrum of the economy right now is our customers are doing everything they can t
componenttext: This is Bill. Yes, we've been talking about it really for the better part of the year, I guess. And what we're seeing out there is I think what you're seeing across all the spectrum of the economy right now is our customers are doing everything they can to improve their service to their customers, and at the same time, manage their bottom line more effectively. And part of the equation is to get more people in their restaurants, and part of it is managing costs. So we're regularly working with customers on how to do that. As I mentioned in my comments, we tend to focus largely on differentiating ourselves and giving them a lot of the value-added services that we've talked about in the past. From a pricing standpoint, I think probably about this time a year ago, it was when it really, I think, went to another level, and it continues to be quite competitive out there. So as you know and as we've talked before, the way we manage the business here is we obviously focus on the top line and we focus on the bottom line, and then we try to manage our expenses in a way that will leverage that, and at the same time, offset any gross margin pressures we may see.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe if you could talk about sales, is there anything that you can point out either regionally or type of customer where you're seeing either the greatest improvement or the least improvement, anything that kind of stands out?
componenttext: Maybe if you could talk about sales, is there anything that you can point out either regionally or type of customer where you're seeing either the greatest improvement or the least improvement, anything that kind of stands out?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: We look at that. Now we got all different ways to slice and dice it here with the new organization structure. We look at it weekly and monthly and quarterly, and I'd be hard pressed to tell you there's any one region that's particularly outperforming anot
componenttext: We look at that. Now we got all different ways to slice and dice it here with the new organization structure. We look at it weekly and monthly and quarterly, and I'd be hard pressed to tell you there's any one region that's particularly outperforming another. Florida continues to be difficult. This is going on three years now.  Hopefully, we're going to start seeing some improvement down there. But I can't really tell you geographically that there's a big trend or variability one way or another. As far as the customer mix, that's an interesting question because as with all numbers, whether you're talking about your earnings or your sales, your margins or your mix, you got to look at where you were last year and where you are now. So there's different views out there in terms of what the industry is seeing. I would say that we're seeing about the same performance both on the QSRs. We're seeing on, say, the meat companies is what we're seeing on the more family-oriented dining with our broadline, but for different reasons. QSR, I think, those numbers -- SYGMA's performing quite well right now. The top line comparisons are a little tougher than a year ago. On the meat company side, we've had two really, really hard years there. As you can appreciate, the bulk of that business is, at least the large percentage of it, is high end, and that's been very difficult segment of the market. Our numbers are actually starting to improve there, albeit off of two tough years. And then in the family dining, I'd say, pretty much mirrors the market. So at least from our perspective, we're not seeing a lot of changes, but part of that is the baseline.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll hear from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next, we'll hear from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on Meredith's question on competition. Just when you think about the source or when you ask about the source of your operators, is this other competitors coming in with just lower pricing? Or is it more a change and maybe even some o
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on Meredith's question on competition. Just when you think about the source or when you ask about the source of your operators, is this other competitors coming in with just lower pricing? Or is it more a change and maybe even some of the bigger independence, let's say, or what have you. Well, actually kind of bidding it out, calling up and saying, we need relief, let's try to create an option for our business.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Andy, I think it's both of those. They tend to be interrelated, but it is more than that. I mean it's also us understanding the depth of the relationships we have with our customers and understanding that even though the environment is better than i
componenttext: Well, Andy, I think it's both of those. They tend to be interrelated, but it is more than that. I mean it's also us understanding the depth of the relationships we have with our customers and understanding that even though the environment is better than it was a year ago, it's still a very tough environment out there for any business. And so we spend a lot of time, invest a lot of resources, both with our Street customers and our contract customers to stay close to them and understand what their needs are and try to be as proactive as we can. So in fairness, is there more of that? What you described probably going on to date and there was a couple of years ago, probably. And are we dealing with it effectively, I think so. But the reality is this business has always very competitive and the margins are relatively slim. So it's a combination of us being proactive and then in certain situations reacting to the specific needs of our customers, which tend to be precipitated by the competition.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: So I mean, let's say, we're in a new economy that doesn't really have a robust rebound. Do you think the attributes of demand for food service distribution might have shifted more towards price and away from quality and reliability? Or could theoretically
componenttext: So I mean, let's say, we're in a new economy that doesn't really have a robust rebound. Do you think the attributes of demand for food service distribution might have shifted more towards price and away from quality and reliability? Or could theoretically have shifted if things don't pick up?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's a shift. I mean, I think it's just a deeper or a more acute emphasis. But certainly, in terms of how we look at the business, both for ourselves and as we work with customers, if you don't have a top line, it's very difficult to leverag
componenttext: I don't think it's a shift. I mean, I think it's just a deeper or a more acute emphasis. But certainly, in terms of how we look at the business, both for ourselves and as we work with customers, if you don't have a top line, it's very difficult to leverage anything. So certainly, you want to make sure your product costs are in line and that your operating costs -- you need to continue to get more productive and more efficient. But I don't think you ever want to move away from what the customer expects relative to your particular eating establishment. So service will continue, we think, to be very, very important. I think it starts there. But with that said, where we are in a slower growth environment, we understand that. And that's why you see us both in the short term over the last few years as well as strategically be very focused on reducing our cost structure over time. That will give us more latitude to continue to compete well.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And just last follow up on the sales environment, it's strengthened at least for the quarter. And I understand you're saying the weeks -- week by week it's still somewhat erratic and I understand that to mean, your operator, your customers are obviously h
componenttext: And just last follow up on the sales environment, it's strengthened at least for the quarter. And I understand you're saying the weeks -- week by week it's still somewhat erratic and I understand that to mean, your operator, your customers are obviously having variable results and so forth. But if you look at it on a monthly basis and including July because the advance sales from commerce look pretty good for July, is there any discernible pattern? Obviously, I'm trying to see if it's up or sideways or can't be down, I suppose. It could be down, I guess, but are you seeing any signs of strengthening when you look for the quarter through July?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, I think what we're trying to address in those comments was we've had several months now. Going back, I think if you look at last year, Chris talked about to have, let's break it into thirds. I mean the first third, we were in a pretty deep dive both
componenttext: Andy, I think what we're trying to address in those comments was we've had several months now. Going back, I think if you look at last year, Chris talked about to have, let's break it into thirds. I mean the first third, we were in a pretty deep dive both on the case volume and on the deflation. We started to see that turn in November and then it did turn in December and last several months. So we're continuing to see case growth even into July will continue to see comparable inflation. The point that we're trying to make there is what we haven't seen is kind of a step up in that rate of growth. And we'd like to see that, but the reality is we haven't seen that. From week-to-week, it will move around and that could be as simple as just how the calendar falls. So the point we're trying to just sense ties it to is, it's choppy but it's definitely still positive. And to your point, there are mixed messages that are coming out of the industry trade right now.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Greg Badishkanian with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Greg Badishkanian with Citi.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow up on the sales question. Obviously, very, very robust volumes relative to how the economy is doing. Market share have anything to do with this versus your other distribution competitors?
componenttext: And just as a follow up on the sales question. Obviously, very, very robust volumes relative to how the economy is doing. Market share have anything to do with this versus your other distribution competitors?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, could you repeat that?
componenttext: Greg, could you repeat that?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing market share gains driving that acceleration in the real sales volume? Or is it strictly kind of the overall market kind of lifting?
componenttext: Are you seeing market share gains driving that acceleration in the real sales volume? Or is it strictly kind of the overall market kind of lifting?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No. We, look at it -- first of all, it's hard to precisely answer that question. The industry numbers continue to get updated, but we think Technomic which tends to be where we go for a lot of our perspective, and we think you're going to see a second yea
componenttext: No. We, look at it -- first of all, it's hard to precisely answer that question. The industry numbers continue to get updated, but we think Technomic which tends to be where we go for a lot of our perspective, and we think you're going to see a second year that's down. So you're looking at two years where the industry has been down and we're flattish to maybe up a little bit, depending on how you look at the numbers. So we think we're taking share, it's just target, getting too aggressive with that comment when the industry's down like that. So no, we're taking share on a relative basis. And we believe, if you look at the industry information that people are in the medium term, a little more optimistic than they were six or 12 months ago for future growth of the market, although in the short term it's not also clear.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just with the recent acquisition of the Lincoln Poultry & Egg, maybe a little bit more color on that? And kind of how you think that's going to do for you?
componenttext: And then just with the recent acquisition of the Lincoln Poultry & Egg, maybe a little bit more color on that? And kind of how you think that's going to do for you?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a very traditional type of Sysco acquisition, it's in a market where we have good market presence. But this is a real good company with a good management team and we think it's going to complement what we're doing out there in the Midwest ver
componenttext: I think it's a very traditional type of Sysco acquisition, it's in a market where we have good market presence. But this is a real good company with a good management team and we think it's going to complement what we're doing out there in the Midwest very well.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll move on to Jason Whitmer with Cleveland Research Company.
componenttext: We'll move on to Jason Whitmer with Cleveland Research Company.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to come back a little bit to your pricing pressure versus trend comment. It seems like competitively not a whole lot different today than maybe over the last 12 months, but maybe can provide some thoughts on the swing in inflation as it rel
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to come back a little bit to your pricing pressure versus trend comment. It seems like competitively not a whole lot different today than maybe over the last 12 months, but maybe can provide some thoughts on the swing in inflation as it relates to pricing power? So it looks like the 2.2% is fully product cost, but how much of that has been realized? Is that what you were talking about? Is it a little bit more of a pinch there in the spread between what you're experiencing in wholesale versus what is getting passed through?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, that could be part of it. I purposely didn't go there just from the standpoint of that's a very hard phenomenon to quantify. We've talked about that in the past. So I think what you're getting at is when you move from a deflationary environment, whic
componenttext: Jay, that could be part of it. I purposely didn't go there just from the standpoint of that's a very hard phenomenon to quantify. We've talked about that in the past. So I think what you're getting at is when you move from a deflationary environment, which while that hurts you on your gross profit dollars, it tends to actually help you to some extent on your percentages and you move into some modest inflation that we're seeing now that could put low pressure. There's a lot of things that obviously impact margins, various components of margin in terms of mix, the product mix, the business mix, the customer mix, all that type of thing, with the numbers were last year. So I think that could be part of it, but I think in the broadest sense in terms of give you a feel for what we're seeing out there, I think it's somewhat of a cumulative build of what we've seen over the last year or just the marketplace where there's just -- everyone's trying to grow and they're trying to -- more than anything, they're trying to make money. So I think that's the bulk of it.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I think where there's some confusion, this would have made more sense two or three or four quarters ago when sales were under pressure, when there's more customer or product mix shift. And now that sales are good and margins at face value look worse. I'm
componenttext: I think where there's some confusion, this would have made more sense two or three or four quarters ago when sales were under pressure, when there's more customer or product mix shift. And now that sales are good and margins at face value look worse. I'm just hoping you can reconcile either the timing of all of that or I mean more importantly, we're trying to get our hands around is where this goes here over the next six months, 12 months within some of those core components whether competitor or not, but just the core components of your business, are there any real inflections to be watching here? Is there something structurally building here before we even get to the SAP expense dollars?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: That's fair. I accept the question. I think what the margins are a little bit like momentum. I mean, they're out there and so while the pressures have been out there for a year or so, it takes a while for some of that pressure to work its way through the
componenttext: That's fair. I accept the question. I think what the margins are a little bit like momentum. I mean, they're out there and so while the pressures have been out there for a year or so, it takes a while for some of that pressure to work its way through the system. And even though, let's say, half of our business is Street business and that tends to get price on a daily or weekly basis. The other half is not, it's contractual and those types of fluctuations tend to take a little longer to work their way through the system. So I think part of it is just a time lag that one would expect over a period of time. And then Jay, part of it is just -- it's how we manage our business. I mean if you run a Sysco operating company, if you run Sysco, you look at your top line, you try to figure out how you're going to grow your bottom line. And we're very focused on the fact that we know it's competitive out there, we know we need to fight hard to continue to earn the business of our existing customers and to grow with them and hopefully attract new customers. So I think it's -- a lot of it is just more the environment. I can't tell you. I don't believe there's a structural change. I don't -- it's still a relatively modest, I think we're off about a quarter of a point for the quarter, we're flat for the year. But I would acknowledge, I think you could see some margin pressure here over the next couple quarters.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Then when you look forward a little bit further out, I know you're trying to tackle 50 basis points of margin expansion just on the core and then another 50 from SAP over time. But where and when should we start seeing, looking for those to develop? Is th
componenttext: Then when you look forward a little bit further out, I know you're trying to tackle 50 basis points of margin expansion just on the core and then another 50 from SAP over time. But where and when should we start seeing, looking for those to develop? Is that something that could be tangible here in the next 12 months? Or is that still a little bit more of a three- or four-year time horizon?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to let Chris jump in on that one.
componenttext: I'm going to let Chris jump in on that one.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll jump in and what you're referring to I think is going back to our Investor Day presentation, what we talked about basically a point of margin improvement, half of which would be our traditional initiatives productivity improvement and half of wh
componenttext: Yes, I'll jump in and what you're referring to I think is going back to our Investor Day presentation, what we talked about basically a point of margin improvement, half of which would be our traditional initiatives productivity improvement and half of which would come from ERP.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: The valid answer to that is as we roll out the tools with ERP, we'll start seeing those improvements. And we're at the very, very early stages of starting to roll out things like Sysco market, eSysco, things of that nature. So over the next 12 months, you
componenttext: The valid answer to that is as we roll out the tools with ERP, we'll start seeing those improvements. And we're at the very, very early stages of starting to roll out things like Sysco market, eSysco, things of that nature. So over the next 12 months, you might see -- we might see bits and pieces of it, but I don't think it's going to be significant enough to flow through to the numbers that you all see. I think it's more likely 24 to 36 months before we start to see the impact as we outlined in our timetable.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, are you talking more about the SAP-specific benefits and the follow-through [ph] from that? Or is there another component just on the core blocking and tackling?
componenttext: Chris, are you talking more about the SAP-specific benefits and the follow-through [ph] from that? Or is there another component just on the core blocking and tackling?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm referring more to the SAP stuff. The core blocking and tackling, what we referred to is the stuff that we are always working on. And I think we spoke about the initiatives that were already underway that we just haven't fully rolled out and the new in
componenttext: I'm referring more to the SAP stuff. The core blocking and tackling, what we referred to is the stuff that we are always working on. And I think we spoke about the initiatives that were already underway that we just haven't fully rolled out and the new initiatives, I think we talked about gas points [ph], some other things that we had barely touched upon yet that would be rolled out over time. Those are the types of things that are always ongoing that were used to offset the normal increases that we see in our cost structure.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, just to add here because certainly the questions are on point, but there's a lot of numbers in this quarter's release and Chris has done a great job, taking you through some of the clunkiness of it. But I would just point out that while there is some
componenttext: Jay, just to add here because certainly the questions are on point, but there's a lot of numbers in this quarter's release and Chris has done a great job, taking you through some of the clunkiness of it. But I would just point out that while there is some legitimate margin pressure out there and we certainly are acknowledging that, when you adjust for the week and you adjust for the COLI, and we're very pleased with the quality of the earnings growth at the operating level this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Move on to Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Move on to Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: With the case volumes steadily improving, where do you stand on the redistribution centers at this point?
componenttext: With the case volumes steadily improving, where do you stand on the redistribution centers at this point?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're more optimistic, obviously. We did defer moving forward in the Midwest because a big part of that business case is generated by anticipated case growth. So we're close to moving forward there, haven't quite pulled together all the administrativ
componenttext: Yes. We're more optimistic, obviously. We did defer moving forward in the Midwest because a big part of that business case is generated by anticipated case growth. So we're close to moving forward there, haven't quite pulled together all the administrative things that we need to do, but we're prepared to move forward here, hopefully next year and will come back to you on that in the Midwest. And that's a very key third leg now in the RDC initiative.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And just to get at your point, the costs were managed well this year. Are you finding any new opportunities for cost cutting as you're going through the SAP process? Or is that kind of already reflected in your comment that 24 to 36 months away, we'll sta
componenttext: And just to get at your point, the costs were managed well this year. Are you finding any new opportunities for cost cutting as you're going through the SAP process? Or is that kind of already reflected in your comment that 24 to 36 months away, we'll start to see some cost improvements?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Chris, I'll jump in on that. I think as we go through the ERP implementation process, if you just back up and think about what we're doing, we're redesigning all of the processes by which we conduct our business. Did we get them all down on paper
componenttext: This is Chris, I'll jump in on that. I think as we go through the ERP implementation process, if you just back up and think about what we're doing, we're redesigning all of the processes by which we conduct our business. Did we get them all down on paper when we first started the initiative? No. So as we pursue this and go through the process of implementing the change, I think it's fair to say we're finding new stuff that we can go to work on and new places where we might be able to do things either more efficiently or less expensively. Did they amount to a significantly increased savings amount compared to our business case? No. But the answer to your question is I think we're always finding new ways to save and improve as we go through this process. Because again, we're redesigning business kind of from the ground up.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe putting SAP aside, you were moving forward, rehiring MAs. How does that stand? And should we be looking for cost to gradually be up in percentage terms this year? Or what should we be thinking about for our SG&A numbers?
componenttext: And then maybe putting SAP aside, you were moving forward, rehiring MAs. How does that stand? And should we be looking for cost to gradually be up in percentage terms this year? Or what should we be thinking about for our SG&A numbers?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start and let Chris clean it up here a little bit. So on the SG&A side, we would continue to expect to leverage those numbers to the extent that we get sales growth. So to specific question MAs, we are up now year-over-year on MAs, and that was somet
componenttext: I'll start and let Chris clean it up here a little bit. So on the SG&A side, we would continue to expect to leverage those numbers to the extent that we get sales growth. So to specific question MAs, we are up now year-over-year on MAs, and that was something that we had fallen behind on. But I would tell you this, the only area that we see any meaningful headcount increase for the new year, given the levels of volume we're seeing today, would be on the sales and marketing side. So we would certainly expect to leverage the SG&A line. Now with that, I mean we have cut quite hard here over the last two years in terms of headcount. So we do need to see some growth to attain that leverage.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just jump in on that, I was doing some quick numbers last night. From Q4 of this year looking back two years to Q4 of 2008, our headcount is down just shy of 4,000, close to 8% and that includes the fact that we've now started rehiring MAs. And so ou
componenttext: I'll just jump in on that, I was doing some quick numbers last night. From Q4 of this year looking back two years to Q4 of 2008, our headcount is down just shy of 4,000, close to 8% and that includes the fact that we've now started rehiring MAs. And so our MA headcount has actually started to grow back in the last couple of quarters. So I'll echo Bill's comment. I think the company did exactly what it needed to do given where cases were going and where the economy was going. We cut very hard and appropriately. We started hiring MAs back because we do believe the market's turning and we are starting to see case growth. At some point, we will have to give serious consideration to whether we start hiring back in some other areas as well to prepare ourselves for larger amounts in business and growth.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll hear from Neil Currie with UBS.
componenttext: Next, we'll hear from Neil Currie with UBS.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to just clarify on the gross margin decline. Will you say that the decline was all price? Or was there anything else in there?
componenttext: Just wanted to just clarify on the gross margin decline. Will you say that the decline was all price? Or was there anything else in there?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's never on price, obviously. Not to be too much on a count on it. But it's your cost of goods and your price, so it's both and it's also mix in terms of the product mix and the customer mix. So there's a little bit of all of that, but I would say
componenttext: Well, it's never on price, obviously. Not to be too much on a count on it. But it's your cost of goods and your price, so it's both and it's also mix in terms of the product mix and the customer mix. So there's a little bit of all of that, but I would say a lot of it is on the pricing side.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And just in terms of you're starting to see inflation compared to last quarter starting to pick up now. Could you just go into which categories you're seeing the strongest price increases and perhaps comment on your ability to pass through these price inc
componenttext: And just in terms of you're starting to see inflation compared to last quarter starting to pick up now. Could you just go into which categories you're seeing the strongest price increases and perhaps comment on your ability to pass through these price increases. And where do you see this going over the next six months or so?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part because that's easier and we'll open it up here to the second part. But we're actually at a pretty nice level right now. 2%, as we said historically, we've seen it all here in last three years. We've seen deflation, we saw a lot o
componenttext: I'll take the first part because that's easier and we'll open it up here to the second part. But we're actually at a pretty nice level right now. 2%, as we said historically, we've seen it all here in last three years. We've seen deflation, we saw a lot of inflation for a bit while than we saw deflation. If we could maintain a relatively constant environment of two or maybe three points of inflation, that tends to work for our customers. It works for us and our systems and that type of thing. That's about where we are at right now. The particular categories, I think, we mentioned where we're seeing the most inflation right now would be in the -- I think it's in dairy and the meat area and the produce area. Now the second part of your question is a much tougher one to answer in terms of where it's going, with some of the phenomenon that's going on with wheat prices and what that might mean within the food chain over time. So you're hearing people talk about deflation in terms of the broader economy on one hand, and then perhaps a lot of inflation in some of the commodities on the other and right now we haven't experienced that. Our inflation report for July was comparable to what we saw for the quarter, but we'll have to watch that very closely. Chris, you want to add anything to that?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean you all are seeing the press releases from other companies that are warning about commodity prices over the next quarter or two. We read the same stuff and so if all that comes to bear, we'll have some inflationary pressure. But our sources abo
componenttext: No, I mean you all are seeing the press releases from other companies that are warning about commodity prices over the next quarter or two. We read the same stuff and so if all that comes to bear, we'll have some inflationary pressure. But our sources about the same as yours.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of how you handle that, either we just look to pass through or wait to see how customers feel about it? Or a lot of it is just contractual?
componenttext: In terms of how you handle that, either we just look to pass through or wait to see how customers feel about it? Or a lot of it is just contractual?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, some of it is contractual to your point, since some of that roll on a weekly and some on a monthly basis. And then on the Street side, we just work through it with customers like we do in any sales or marketing opportunities. But generally, like I s
componenttext: Well, some of it is contractual to your point, since some of that roll on a weekly and some on a monthly basis. And then on the Street side, we just work through it with customers like we do in any sales or marketing opportunities. But generally, like I said, when you're at lower levels, it's something they can handle more than what we were seeing a couple of weeks ago when we were at 6% and 8% inflation.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll hear from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Now we'll hear from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Just first, a quick clarification, on the ERP EPS investment in fiscal '11, I think you said, Chris, $0.06 to $0.09?
componenttext: Just first, a quick clarification, on the ERP EPS investment in fiscal '11, I think you said, Chris, $0.06 to $0.09?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Now is that incremental relative to '10 or in total?
componenttext: Now is that incremental relative to '10 or in total?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: When we use the term incremental what we're basically saying is that $0.06 to $0.09 of additional costs that we would not otherwise incur where we're not doing the ERP implementation. You would then take that number, whatever it is, between $0.06 to $0.09
componenttext: When we use the term incremental what we're basically saying is that $0.06 to $0.09 of additional costs that we would not otherwise incur where we're not doing the ERP implementation. You would then take that number, whatever it is, between $0.06 to $0.09 and compare it to $0.02, which is what we reported this year and that's the year-over-year change.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: And secondly, in terms of I guess some of the restructuring, if you will, the operating companies with some regional supervision and I think, Bill, you mentioned in terms of that, that would give you, a, give you a better look for some acquisitions but al
componenttext: And secondly, in terms of I guess some of the restructuring, if you will, the operating companies with some regional supervision and I think, Bill, you mentioned in terms of that, that would give you, a, give you a better look for some acquisitions but also serve customers across geographies. Of course, I immediately think about change. I mean, do you think that there are any change or might that become more strategically important over time to add some big chunks of business that might currently reside with some of your competition on the chain side?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-16-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we believe we certainly have opportunity on the contract sales side. With that said, the Street business is very, very important part of our business model so we need to focus on both. But to your point, what we're really saying to you there is we b
componenttext: Well, we believe we certainly have opportunity on the contract sales side. With that said, the Street business is very, very important part of our business model so we need to focus on both. But to your point, what we're really saying to you there is we believe whether it's regional chains or even national chains where maybe more of a market type of emphasis within that group. These are sometimes big groups. We think just having the type of people that we put in these jobs were highly experienced, very accomplished people within Sysco, many of them have a very strong sales background. We certainly think the customer and the sales opportunity is something we can capitalize there, along with the acquisition. But it's also an opportunity just when you gotten as large as we have and as geographically dispersed, I think that level of management will allow some of us to stay focused on the key drivers to the business over time.
