headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2011 Earnings Results Conference Call. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2011 Earnings Results Conference Call. At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's First Quarter 2011 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Sysco's First Quarter 2011 Conference Call. On today's call, you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made on the course of this presentation that states the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ in a material manner from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings, including, but not limited to, risk factors contained in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended July 3, 2010, and in the company's press release issued earlier this morning.
On the call today, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. You can find the reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures on our Investor Relations website at sysco.com. Also, all comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted. 
Lastly, we would like to remind you that our Investor Day is scheduled for December 2. If you haven't already registered, please do so prior to November 22. With that out of the way, I'll turn the call over to our President and Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Neil. Good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported net earnings of $299 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2011. Our sales in the first quarter increased 7.4%, driven mainly by increased case volume and estimated food cost inflation o
componenttext:
Thanks, Neil. Good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported net earnings of $299 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2011. Our sales in the first quarter increased 7.4%, driven mainly by increased case volume and estimated food cost inflation of 3.3%.
Case volume was higher across all regions in our Broadline and SYGMA segments, and the year-over-year increase represented the strongest improvement since the second quarter of fiscal 2007. While the pace of the macroeconomic recovery remains sluggish and restaurant traffic patterns continue to be under pressure, recent data suggests the industry is slowly recovering. Sysco's gradual but consistent improvement in case volume confirms this trend and we believe we are continuing to grow our market share.
We are pleased with our sales growth for the quarter, and I should also note that we achieved record first quarter operating income. Nevertheless, operating income growth over the prior year was less than our sales increase as improved expense management was more than offset by a 46 basis point decline in gross margin percent.
Several factors contributed to the decline in gross margins. Approximately 10 points of the margin decline related to a change in business mix. While both our Broadline and SYGMA businesses grew this quarter, segment grew at a faster rate, and since SYGMA operates lower margin business, this mix shift impacted total margins. We do not view this as a negative outcome. As a matter fact, we see a great deal of opportunity on the contract side of the business, both in the Broadline and SYGMA segments. The key is to strike an appropriate balance between street and contract sales growths over time.
The remainder of the gross margin decline was split about evenly between two drivers. The first is a set of ongoing strategic pricing initiatives designed to drive volume increases in targeted categories. While these initiatives are putting near-term pressure on our margins, we are starting to see double-digit volume increases for these programs have been effectively implemented. We expect this specific pressure on gross margins will persist in the near term, but we also believe these initiatives will result in profitable market share gains over time.
The last component of the gross margin decline relates to the significant rates of inflation in the meat, dairy and seafood categories, which together, approached 10%. While we typically are able to pass through modest levels of price inflation on a timely basis, it is more difficult in the short term to pass through double digit price increases to our customers without negatively impacting their business. 
Our ongoing productivity initiatives help to mitigate a portion of the gross margin pressure with U.S. Broadline warehouse cases per man-hour and cases per trip increasing compared to last year's first quarter. In addition, total sales per employee also increased year-over-year.
All that said, while operating performance in the first quarter is acceptable, it is not up to our standards. We recently held our annual senior leadership meeting at which the importance of profitable sales growth was clearly discussed. Our management team understands that we must find ways to grow earnings faster than sales during these challenging times.
Turning to our multiyear business transformation initiative for a moment, the project remains on track. We are preparing to begin the last of our four cycles of testing prior to go live at our pilot facility early next year. We are also beginning to staff Sysco Business Services and have recently named Kirk Drummond to lead this strategically important part of our business. Kirk has been with Sysco for the last 24 years, working in various capacities at our local operating companies and the corporate, including five years as our Chief Information Officer and the last five years as our Senior Vice President and Treasurer. This organization will centralize back office administrative functions such as accounting, receivables, payables, billing and call center support. 
I'd like to close by thanking our associates and our management team for their ongoing contributions and commitment to Sysco's success. This is an exciting time in our company's history and our associates continue to deliver a high level of service and support to our customers. While our businesses face uncertain challenges, we remain dedicated to being our customers' most valued business partner and to invest in the future growth of Sysco. We know this focus strengthens our competitive position and provides a strong foundation for success over the long term. 
Now I'll turn things over to Chris so he can provide additional details on our financial results for the quarter.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the first quarter, sales were $9.8 million or an increase of 7.4% compared to the prior year, driven mainly by case volume growth and the impact of food cost inflation, which we estimate to be 3.3% for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the first quarter, sales were $9.8 million or an increase of 7.4% compared to the prior year, driven mainly by case volume growth and the impact of food cost inflation, which we estimate to be 3.3% for the period. In addition, acquisitions within the last 12 months increased sales by 0.6%, and changes in foreign exchange rate increased sales by 0.5%. 
Operating income increased $9 million or 1.8% to $506 million during the quarter. While sales increased 7.4%, gross margin increased only 4.8% and operating expense increased 6%. 
Operating expense increased $75 million for the quarter due to three main drivers. First, salaries and related expense increased approximately $40 million, primarily from increased case volume during the quarter, including increased commissions and incentives and delivery personnel cost. Total headcount was down very slightly compared to the prior year, meaning we held our headcount levels relatively steady despite increased case volume. While total headcount is down, we've increased MA headcount over the last year. It typically takes one to two years for an MA to be fully productive within the sales organization, but we consider this investment in the business to be an important one that will enhance our ability to grow sales as the industry recovers and continue to take market share.
Second, as we had discussed on last quarter's call, pension expense increased by $15 million year-over-year. Lastly, operating expense included a $14 million benefit from the impact of Corporate-Owned Life Insurance, or COLI, which is an unfavorable comparison to the $21 million benefit we recorded in the prior year.
Net earnings for the first quarter were $299 million, declining $27 million or 8.3% compared to the prior year. Net earnings reflected $39 million year-over-year increase in tax expense, primarily due to the IRS settlement gain and higher non-taxable COLI gains recorded in the prior year. Excluding the impact of COLI in both periods and the IRS settlement gain, net earnings for the quarter as adjusted would have increased 3.4%. In addition, the $15 million year-over-year increase in pension expense impacted net earnings by another 2.8 percentage points.
Earnings per share declined 7.3% to $0.51, which included a $0.02 benefit from COLI. In the prior year period, earnings per share were $0.55 and included a $0.05 gain related to the IRS settlement and a $0.04 benefit from COLI.
Turning to cash flow. Cash flow from operations for the fiscal year was $227 million compared to $42 million in the prior year. Cash flow from operations increased year-over-year due mainly to the timing of our IRS settlement payments. During the first quarter of this year, we had no settlement payments. However, in the prior year period, we paid $316 million. We expect to pay a total of $212 million in settlement payments during this fiscal year and again, next year. As a reminder, these scheduled payments included $106 million cash outflow in the second quarter period and a $53 million cash outflow in the third and fourth fiscal quarters.
Cash flow from operations was negatively impacted during the quarter by an increase in accounts receivable and a decline in accrued expense. Receivables increased due to the higher sales during the period, and the decline in accrued expenses this quarter was due mainly to the payment of incentive compensation related to the prior fiscal year. 
Capital expenditures totaled $143 million for the quarter, including facility expansion and replacement, fleet replacements and investments in technology, including our business transformation project.
In closing, while the business environment remains challenging, we are seeing improvements and our operating companies continue to have a strong focus on growing cases, controlling costs, improving productivity and successfully implementing our business transformation. As a result, we are confident that Sysco is well positioned to take advantage of the economic recovery as it takes hold. 
With that, operator, we will now take questions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to clarify a few things on the gross margin impact during the quarter. I think some of that decline, I'm sure, is a little bit cosmetic because of the inflation impact. And Bill, I think you already talked about the mix shift between SYGMA a
componenttext: I just wanted to clarify a few things on the gross margin impact during the quarter. I think some of that decline, I'm sure, is a little bit cosmetic because of the inflation impact. And Bill, I think you already talked about the mix shift between SYGMA and Broadline. But as far as the strategic price investments that I think you cited in your press release, it seems, at least to me, a little bit unprecedented for Sysco to have to resort to discounting based on where you guys have typically gone to market. So can you just talk about how far reaching these price investments are going to be over the rest of the year? And if you had to quantify, how much of the 46 basis point decline was driven by a price investments in this last quarter? Is that something that you can qualify at all?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll give it my best shot and we'll see where we end up here. So to repeat, of the 46 basis point decline, we think about 10 of that is a business mix of SYGMA versus the Broadline, so that leaves you over a third of a point of margin decline. And our bes
componenttext: I'll give it my best shot and we'll see where we end up here. So to repeat, of the 46 basis point decline, we think about 10 of that is a business mix of SYGMA versus the Broadline, so that leaves you over a third of a point of margin decline. And our best estimate is about half of that is we would attribute to pretty significant inflation in those three categories I mentioned: meat, dairy and seafood. And the other half, too, I don't know that I would call it discounting or pricing so much. What we would characterize it, as what we said, is strategic category initiatives where we see opportunities, Ajay, where we're somewhat under penetrated and we think it's appropriate for us to get a little more focused and give a little more finely priced in those categories. So we've been into this year for a few months and I will expect it to continue here over a good portion of the balance of the year. But it's not a random type of thing. It's distinct categories, and we're doing it in different parts of the country and over time throughout the country. And again, I would expect us to maybe not in 12 months but over a reasonable period of time see a payback there on the sales month.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So going forward, with the gross margin implications from these category management initiatives, would the magnitude be similar to these latest quarter?
componenttext: So going forward, with the gross margin implications from these category management initiatives, would the magnitude be similar to these latest quarter?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's really hard to predict. I mean, there's a lot of things that go in the gross margin, Ajay. But I would say, for this piece of the pie, so to speak, I think as we said in -- I think as I said in the narrative, expect the pressure to continue here fo
componenttext: That's really hard to predict. I mean, there's a lot of things that go in the gross margin, Ajay. But I would say, for this piece of the pie, so to speak, I think as we said in -- I think as I said in the narrative, expect the pressure to continue here for at least a couple of more quarters. With that said, I think there's other things we can manage better, including the inflation part and that's what we were alluding to in terms of our discussions with our management team. There's opportunities for us to manage this inflation environment somewhat better.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just this one quick follow up. On the tax rate, I know there's some variabilities quarter-based on stock compensation and COLI, but can you talk about what you're assuming as far as a normalized tax rate for the rest of the year?
componenttext: And just this one quick follow up. On the tax rate, I know there's some variabilities quarter-based on stock compensation and COLI, but can you talk about what you're assuming as far as a normalized tax rate for the rest of the year?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ajay, this is Chris. I mean, obviously, a normalized rate for Sysco is probably 38%, 39%. What's going on with the tax rate is primarily driven by the IRS settlement last year and the COLI both last year and this year. Those are two main drivers in the ta
componenttext: Ajay, this is Chris. I mean, obviously, a normalized rate for Sysco is probably 38%, 39%. What's going on with the tax rate is primarily driven by the IRS settlement last year and the COLI both last year and this year. Those are two main drivers in the tax rate.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: But as far as what you're modeling in internally, is 38% to 39% representative of what we should be assuming as well?
componenttext: But as far as what you're modeling in internally, is 38% to 39% representative of what we should be assuming as well?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a normalized tax rate. I'm not really commenting about what we expect for the year to be candid. We don't really know what's going to -- what COLI is going to be for the full year. We start the year off assuming COLI's going to be flat and ob
componenttext: Well, that's a normalized tax rate. I'm not really commenting about what we expect for the year to be candid. We don't really know what's going to -- what COLI is going to be for the full year. We start the year off assuming COLI's going to be flat and obviously, it wasn't flat this first quarter. We got a benefit from it. We don't really know what's going to happen for the duration of the year. I would say, yes, we start the year assuming 38% to 39%. We knew that we are going to have laughing issue in the first quarter in terms of the things that happened in the first quarter last year.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering in case you were kind enough to give us a sense of how much of the gross margin was due to the strategic price investment, maybe you could talk a little bit about how much of the volume, the case volume increase we saw also came from those
componenttext: I was wondering in case you were kind enough to give us a sense of how much of the gross margin was due to the strategic price investment, maybe you could talk a little bit about how much of the volume, the case volume increase we saw also came from those specific categories? I think you said in your prepared remarks that you did get a good response in sales in those categories.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll give you my best shot again here. I think in terms of putting that together, what we did say here is that we are seeing double-digit increases in those categories where we effectively roll these initiatives out, and we're not always through doing tha
componenttext: I'll give you my best shot again here. I think in terms of putting that together, what we did say here is that we are seeing double-digit increases in those categories where we effectively roll these initiatives out, and we're not always through doing that. So it doesn't transcend the entire book of business, so to speak, for the quarter, but we're pleased with the sales growth that we are seeing. That said, there's other categories as well that contributed to the sales growth. And some of which were the same ones that had some pretty significant inflationary pressure. So it's mixed, I guess. So there's not a direct correlation is the short answer.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I have a question about inflation. I know you said that you think that the operators could have done a better job passing it along. But maybe you could talk a little bit about the conditions, I mean, I'm sure they all want to make money, so what
componenttext: And then I have a question about inflation. I know you said that you think that the operators could have done a better job passing it along. But maybe you could talk a little bit about the conditions, I mean, I'm sure they all want to make money, so what the conditions might be that would be making it difficult for them to pass it along? And is it fair to call that price competition?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I said, I want to be really clear because a lot of our people are listening here, too, I said we need to do better going forward. We're fine with the quarter. As I said, it was acceptable. These are very interesting times, in addition to being exciti
componenttext: What I said, I want to be really clear because a lot of our people are listening here, too, I said we need to do better going forward. We're fine with the quarter. As I said, it was acceptable. These are very interesting times, in addition to being exciting times. So you got a situation out here where a year ago, we had about three and a half points and deflation cases were going the wrong way. A year later, we're seeing just the opposite amount of inflation, and we're encouraged by the case growth. So if you look at it on a customer standpoint, our customer standpoint, if you go back three years, we've been through an environment of two years of pretty significant inflation, a third year of deflation and now we're into our fourth year here where inflation is picking up in these certain categories. So I'm not saying that we should have done better. I'm really just saying we need to do better going forward, and our folks understand that. In terms of how you manage that, essentially, you manage it territory by territory, account by account and you look at each situation, and you're always getting an eye on the operating company level. You're always trying to strike the right balance of between opportunities for growth and opportunities to more effectively, more productively serve these accounts with the reality that our customers are running the business as well, and we need to be sensitive to what their high-cost items are and what their key concerns are. So that's why we have 8,000 commissioned salespeople out there, that's why we have presidents in all these operating companies is to make those decisions on an account by account basis and overall, from an enterprise standpoint, we try to give them good guidance and feedback. And then the contract side of the business, the inflation, as we've talked before, impacts a little different. Most of the categories are contractually went to some type of pricing mechanism. And they're typically is up to a 30-day time lag from the time that the pie comes in to when the prices roll. So it depends on whether it's street business or contract business.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: You were talking about the SYGMA business going faster and that you think you generally have opportunities on the contracted side. I was wondering whether the business transformation project is part of what needs to be accomplished for you to go after the
componenttext: You were talking about the SYGMA business going faster and that you think you generally have opportunities on the contracted side. I was wondering whether the business transformation project is part of what needs to be accomplished for you to go after the contracted business more aggressively and make sure that, that brings at least a comparable financial benefit to the company, because it's obviously lower gross margin business.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the business transformation initiatives going to help us on both sides. It'll definitely help us on the street side in terms of, I think, our salespeople having better tools to work with as well as our customers and over time, align our cust
componenttext: Well, I think the business transformation initiatives going to help us on both sides. It'll definitely help us on the street side in terms of, I think, our salespeople having better tools to work with as well as our customers and over time, align our customers to participate I think more actively in what level of service they want, what types of price points, the whole channel of opportunity there. On the contract side, we're starting to see this already but to your point, I think we'll see it more as we have better data and more integrated systems is -- our big opportunity on the contract side is to create a more consistent phase to the customer of all Sysco's capabilities. So when you hear us speak about more effectively integrating our capabilities, we're talking about both on the merchandising, the sales side, as well as across all of our different businesses, SYGMA, FreshPoint, the meat companies, supply, all those types of things. So I think the biggest opportunity on the contract side is just from an enterprise standpoint being able to go after this business more cohesively, and that's what we're looking forward to there.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Mark Wiltamuth with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the business transformation process, when do you think we start to see some of the cost savings falling out of that, because it seems like there's probably duplicative efforts there at the operating company level versus the parent?
componenttext: On the business transformation process, when do you think we start to see some of the cost savings falling out of that, because it seems like there's probably duplicative efforts there at the operating company level versus the parent?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Chris. As we've talked about, we finished the design of the business transformation process. We're going through testing and the fourth round of testing past begin, and we'll start to rollout sometime in the early part of next calendar year.
componenttext: Mark, this is Chris. As we've talked about, we finished the design of the business transformation process. We're going through testing and the fourth round of testing past begin, and we'll start to rollout sometime in the early part of next calendar year. We will actually start to see reductions in cost until we get further into the rollout process, and that's the schedule of numbers that we put up back in December at the Investor Day meeting which we'll update for you this December at the same time. So while we've outlined all the cost and the way we've been doing that is incremental net of benefits, we really don't start seeing significant benefits until fiscal 2013. And in that year, our current estimates again, it'll be updated in December but what we showed you at December was the benefits would offset the cost in 2013, so it'd about breakeven that year and then thereafter, of course, we keep more benefits than costs.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the inflation, what do you think is a comfortable level of inflation to pass through? Where you think get it through and it doesn't kind of shock the system and you don't have problems passing through the margin there?
componenttext: And then on the inflation, what do you think is a comfortable level of inflation to pass through? Where you think get it through and it doesn't kind of shock the system and you don't have problems passing through the margin there?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Chris start with that one, Mark.
componenttext: I'll let Chris start with that one, Mark.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we've always talked about is a small amount of inflation are great for us, one, two, maybe even three points of inflation. We can handle that and our customers can handle that. When you start spiking above that, it causes some problems. We typically
componenttext: What we've always talked about is a small amount of inflation are great for us, one, two, maybe even three points of inflation. We can handle that and our customers can handle that. When you start spiking above that, it causes some problems. We typically believe we can always manage those increases effectively but maybe they may take more time to pass through the system. What we're commenting about this quarter is three categories whereas Bill said, we saw inflation combine in those three categories close to 10%, and that's more than we can pass through at any timely manner. So one, two, three, we can handle that. Our customers can handle that. When you start spiking across the board or in certain categories, it gets more difficult. And these particular categories are meat and seafood especially are fairly high-margin categories.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other point, I think, which I'm sure most people in this call understand is, this challenge is not unique to our industry. It certainly not. There's a lot of companies that are dealing with this growing inflation issues in the product mix righ
componenttext: I think the other point, I think, which I'm sure most people in this call understand is, this challenge is not unique to our industry. It certainly not. There's a lot of companies that are dealing with this growing inflation issues in the product mix right now, so we need to stay close to our customers and for that matter, our suppliers and make good decisions. And I believe you'll see that we'll do that.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Jeff Hans actually on behalf of Greg. Following up on the strategic pricing initiatives that you guys have rolled out as it relates to the overall environment, what do you think from your competitors I guess kind of following those initiatives in
componenttext: This is Jeff Hans actually on behalf of Greg. Following up on the strategic pricing initiatives that you guys have rolled out as it relates to the overall environment, what do you think from your competitors I guess kind of following those initiatives in those specific markets? And I guess just overall, I mean, is the environment still pretty competitive versus where it's been the last few quarters?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say the competitive environment is just that. I think it's comparable to where it's been. People are still very acutely sensitized to case growth and volume growth and getting people under restaurants and their operations, that type of thing. So I don
componenttext: I'd say the competitive environment is just that. I think it's comparable to where it's been. People are still very acutely sensitized to case growth and volume growth and getting people under restaurants and their operations, that type of thing. So I don't think there's been a lot of change there. It would be hard for us to gauge any competitive reaction of this. What I would just say, again, is that we're seeing some good results on our end. So that's coming from someplace, and we're just pleased with what we're seeing. And the only point we're trying to make today is that it did impact that margin and probably we'll hear for a few more couple more quarters anyway, but we think it's an appropriate opportunity for us to take advantage of.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one last one, I guess, in terms of the trending case volume growth into October and maybe early November, did that kind of continue at the rate you saw in your fiscal 1Q and also kind of the rate of inflation I guess in October, November as well, if
componenttext: Just one last one, I guess, in terms of the trending case volume growth into October and maybe early November, did that kind of continue at the rate you saw in your fiscal 1Q and also kind of the rate of inflation I guess in October, November as well, if that kind of accelerated or just stayed constant?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't typically give a lot of guidance or updates in terms of the quarter. But I think I would say this to you, there's been, I think, a more favorable sentiment in the marketplace. We've tried to signal that in our comments here this morning. So
componenttext: Well, we don't typically give a lot of guidance or updates in terms of the quarter. But I think I would say this to you, there's been, I think, a more favorable sentiment in the marketplace. We've tried to signal that in our comments here this morning. So we're encouraged with the volume growth that we're seeing right now. And at the same time, I think from what we read and what we feel on our side of the business, I don't think the inflation's going to abate any time soon.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: What is prompting price competition in an improving environment? I mean, it just seems counterintuitive in most industries? And certainly, how foodservice distribution as I know it is sort of historically structured? The industry is a lot for things that
componenttext: What is prompting price competition in an improving environment? I mean, it just seems counterintuitive in most industries? And certainly, how foodservice distribution as I know it is sort of historically structured? The industry is a lot for things that better that price competition ease seems counterintuitive.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take a shot at this and if I don't give any, you can come back to me. Look, we need to put this in some type of context. This industry has always been highly competitive. There's a lot of competitors out there, there's a lot of different people
componenttext: Well, I'll take a shot at this and if I don't give any, you can come back to me. Look, we need to put this in some type of context. This industry has always been highly competitive. There's a lot of competitors out there, there's a lot of different people with different business models and different agendas. So there's always competition. I think maybe to your point, we're in an inflection point right now in this cycle and what I was to trying to describe earlier is if you look at it over a three-year period, I'm no foodservice historian, but I don't know that we've ever had a three-year period like this where you had two years of a lot of inflation, a lot of pressure on our customers, then you have a year of deflation. Now we're finally starting to see some case growth and we think the industry's showing a little bit signs of recovery. But there's still a lot of sensitivity out there at the operators side, on the distributors side in terms of growth and how we continue to advance the ball in our respective businesses. So this favorable turn, albeit modest turn, let's be clear, we're talking about maybe 2% or 3% growth in our line of business. We're not talking 7% or 8% growth real growth. So I think it's still a very competitive out there. And I think people's memories are long right now and everyone's doing everything they can to not just improve their business, but to be prepared for any surprises that come down the road here over the next six to 12 months. So I think it's more just a waiting impact of what we've been through the last two to three years.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to jump in to just add one thing. I think we've mentioned it but mentioned it again, last year, at this time, they were reporting deflation of I think 3.4% in my number [indiscernible]. But we went from a negative 3.4% to a positive 3.3% in a fa
componenttext: I'm going to jump in to just add one thing. I think we've mentioned it but mentioned it again, last year, at this time, they were reporting deflation of I think 3.4% in my number [indiscernible]. But we went from a negative 3.4% to a positive 3.3% in a fairly short period of time and we saw that volatility causes a lot of uncomfortable that's out there in the market, so we're going with that as now.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: To your point, we have an opportunity manages better as I said and we're committed to doing that.
componenttext: To your point, we have an opportunity manages better as I said and we're committed to doing that.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me ask you specifically on this DMA, this consortium of regionals, they just want -- I think the McCormick & Schmick's contract from you guys, so is that on price? And if so, is that -- what I'm trying to figure out is how deep is this price competiti
componenttext: Let me ask you specifically on this DMA, this consortium of regionals, they just want -- I think the McCormick & Schmick's contract from you guys, so is that on price? And if so, is that -- what I'm trying to figure out is how deep is this price competition? Is that what you would consider just that kind of normal give and takes and there's plenty of stuff you want, or is there like -- the capacity utilization that some of these distributors might be at, it's on inflection point where the marginal cost are de minimis or they might as well they've kind of low-end contracts. I'm just trying to understand a little more what the market dynamics the way they are.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair. I think the only thing I'm going to comment specifically is that it relates to [indiscernible]. We're disappointed we lost the business. It was good business for us. And in terms of what triggered that decision, I'm not exactly sure. It'
componenttext: Yes, that's fair. I think the only thing I'm going to comment specifically is that it relates to [indiscernible]. We're disappointed we lost the business. It was good business for us. And in terms of what triggered that decision, I'm not exactly sure. It'd probably be all of the above. With that said, we're encouraged with what we're doing right now on the contract side, both in SYGMA and on the multi-unit sales portion of our Broadline business. Larry Pulliam and Kent Humphries and their team. We've got a lot of momentum there. We've made some organization moves. We're much more focused on segments and that type of thing. We'll talk more about it in December. But you never want to lose business. That's something we're working very hard on throughout our company to minimize those situations. But I can tell you, we're bringing on business as well, and we feel very good about the direction in that area.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last thing, where you aren't using pricing to when share business and share, is it more with getting actually new customers or is it more expanding into new lines with existing customers? And kind of getting to sometimes in this industry, you can
componenttext: And the last thing, where you aren't using pricing to when share business and share, is it more with getting actually new customers or is it more expanding into new lines with existing customers? And kind of getting to sometimes in this industry, you can win customers and then the margins kind of normalized.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit of both. I don't know that I can break that down for you. Certainly, the most profitable sale we could make is an incremental sale with an existing customer. So I think there's plenty of opportunity there. It's also an opportunity to put
componenttext: It's a little bit of both. I don't know that I can break that down for you. Certainly, the most profitable sale we could make is an incremental sale with an existing customer. So I think there's plenty of opportunity there. It's also an opportunity to put our best foot forward with prospects. I think it's both.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

componenttext: No, we didn't comment about it because it was not a material change quarter-over-quarter, and our guidance has not changed from the 10-K.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow up on the previous question. Over the last couple of years, your case volumes significantly exceeded that of restaurant traffic as I understand it as reported by the chains. The question is this, where has your sales growth come from? Have t
componenttext: Just a follow up on the previous question. Over the last couple of years, your case volumes significantly exceeded that of restaurant traffic as I understand it as reported by the chains. The question is this, where has your sales growth come from? Have they come from sales to existing accounts or as you just mentioned, lower margin sales to new accounts? What do you anticipate that mix in general going forward? And do you have a good sense for your existing accounts how your share has changed over the past couple of years and is there like a medium-term target we could possibly think about?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, it's similar. And I'm going to need you to come back. It's essentially coming from both. I mean, we certainly want to participate in the growth of our existing customers. We [indiscernible] everyday out there trying to improve our store wallet with
componenttext: John, it's similar. And I'm going to need you to come back. It's essentially coming from both. I mean, we certainly want to participate in the growth of our existing customers. We [indiscernible] everyday out there trying to improve our store wallet with those folks, and we do believe we've been able to do that. Now that's hard to quantify and hard to sometimes say with a straight face when the industry has done and decline for a year to two years. But we certainly think that we've improved our share wallet and taken share for that matter in all segments. I think what's helped us a little bit in the overall numbers relative to the restaurant numbers is about 30% of our business or a little bit more than that 35%, I guess, is non-restaurant business. So we continue to do well in the institutional side of things and that's certainly been a buffer for us through these difficult times. But our approach in our model hasn't change. We want to grow with our current customers. We want to help them grow. But as we've talked before and as we'll talk more in December, there is plenty of opportunity for us both on the street side, as well as the contract side of this business to bring on new business. And the last piece of this and a part that we continue to focus on even more is to protect the business that we have and share those with customers that have been very well for us over the years.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Bob Summers with Susquehanna.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Bob Summers with Susquehanna.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to get my arms around the variable labor component of the model a bit and understand. And I appreciate this is a big picture look, but why an $84 million increase in gross profit dollars drives about a $40 million increase in salaries and
componenttext: I'm just trying to get my arms around the variable labor component of the model a bit and understand. And I appreciate this is a big picture look, but why an $84 million increase in gross profit dollars drives about a $40 million increase in salaries and related items? I guess, on the surface that seems rather aggressive path.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start. I think Chris is winding up here. So he's got some more specifics on this deal. But essentially, what we try to explain is, just in general, you've got some incentive increases there at the management side. Well, we hear talk about first
componenttext: Well, I'll start. I think Chris is winding up here. So he's got some more specifics on this deal. But essentially, what we try to explain is, just in general, you've got some incentive increases there at the management side. Well, we hear talk about first steady improvements, we continue to be pleased with what we're seeing on the operational side of the business as well as on the admin side. Now the one thing we have done and we've talked about this and we'll continue to do is we have more aggressively invested in our sales force here over the last six months or so, and those numbers are beginning to populate themselves both in terms of the number of MAs on the street as well as trainees. So that does translate into higher commissions with the sales growth and into higher fixed investment on the selling payroll side as we try to get back on track in terms of our headcount and sales. So without being real specific here, I'm just trying to bifurcate that for you in terms of we're pleased with what we're seeing operationally in the admin side in terms of productivity, but we are investing in sales folks and have been over the last three to six months.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

componenttext: I think you actually had the numbers. I mean, obviously, we started with a gross margin number that was lower than we would have liked, and then the payout came out at lower numbers. It comes back to leverage and your specifically focusing on the labor side of the equation, I think that's the answer.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then second, can you just talk a little bit about Sysco brand sales? If I'm looking at this table that you have in the back properly, did the penetration rate go down?
componenttext: And then second, can you just talk a little bit about Sysco brand sales? If I'm looking at this table that you have in the back properly, did the penetration rate go down?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a trend that we've seen now for the better part of two years. So our brand sales are off. And as we've been talking, we're concerned about that to a point. Obviously, you need to sell customers what they need and they want, but we do have some
componenttext: Yes, that's a trend that we've seen now for the better part of two years. So our brand sales are off. And as we've been talking, we're concerned about that to a point. Obviously, you need to sell customers what they need and they want, but we do have some opportunities there. And internally, we're doing a lot of work in that area. And I think you'll see some progress there. But it takes a while to move the needle on that. But we are very focused on that. But again, we need to approach that in a way that works for the customer base. And that's the balancing act that we're dealing with at this point.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, agreed. But if I were to think of is there an attending gross margin drag associated with that change? Just trying to think through another component of the gross margin.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tends to get woven into the other factors, the other two factors I was talking about, so I can't tell you that I can call that out specifically. But certainly, over time, I think it's clear that when we are able to sell Sysco branded items with that, that
componenttext: Tends to get woven into the other factors, the other two factors I was talking about, so I can't tell you that I can call that out specifically. But certainly, over time, I think it's clear that when we are able to sell Sysco branded items with that, that does translate to more leverage on that on the earnings line.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Heinbockel [ph] with Guggenheim.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Heinbockel [ph] with Guggenheim.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, John, look, I know I'm sounding a little bit like a broken record. It's a little of the latter and a lot of the former I think. So there's always opportunities as we work with our suppliers to make sure that we're controlling our cost, and we do a g
componenttext: Well, John, look, I know I'm sounding a little bit like a broken record. It's a little of the latter and a lot of the former I think. So there's always opportunities as we work with our suppliers to make sure that we're controlling our cost, and we do a good job of that and we certainly work very hard on that. The flip side is I think where we signaling to you in terms of where we're at and what we need to do is it's really more about focus I think, and we've got the best people in the industry, we got great President, we got 8,000 salespeople, they've got great DSMs working with them. So it's essentially what I was talking about earlier, which is looking at each customer, each territory, each operating company and just making good decisions on striking the right balance for in terms of what the customers acute needs are and where we need and how that translates into moving boxes versus price versus cost efficiency. So I'm going to just leave it at focused internally where we think we can do better than what we have, and I expect that we will over time.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I can't say that we have seen that. We're seeing pretty good growth in some of those categories.
componenttext: No, I can't say that we have seen that. We're seeing pretty good growth in some of those categories.

componenttext: You need more than just double digit to make that work in the short term. So what you heard me say, John, was I think there's opportunities out there for us, but it may take more than a year to get the full payback on that type of initiative.

componenttext: Let me try to be clear here. So there's some cascading effect here. And it's not a six-month payback, I guess, is what I'm trying to say.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's an excellent point and that's all part of it that's why we used the word strategic here, which is some of that opportunity is to solidify our relationships with customers and grow not just on those items but within that category and ideally, across
componenttext: That's an excellent point and that's all part of it that's why we used the word strategic here, which is some of that opportunity is to solidify our relationships with customers and grow not just on those items but within that category and ideally, across categories. So that's exactly what we're trying to do here.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've learned it's a lot of hard work, we've got people working a lot of hours down here and there's just a lot of complexity, a lot of detail to it and we're staying the course. We're doing everything we can to minimize the surprises once we go to the fi
componenttext: We've learned it's a lot of hard work, we've got people working a lot of hours down here and there's just a lot of complexity, a lot of detail to it and we're staying the course. We're doing everything we can to minimize the surprises once we go to the first pilot here.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Bob Cummins with Wellington Shields.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder you could give us a broad overview on the state of the restaurant industry in general now. Are we in an early stage of recovery? Are the operators still complaining? Is there business still down? Where are we going? Are we in an uptrend as yet?
componenttext: I wonder you could give us a broad overview on the state of the restaurant industry in general now. Are we in an early stage of recovery? Are the operators still complaining? Is there business still down? Where are we going? Are we in an uptrend as yet?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a part of me that wants to say yes. Certainly, the science we've seen since late summer, Bob, are encouraging. Some of the reports are coming out and data, both in terms of what the restaurants are seeing in terms of their volume and getting
componenttext: Well, there's a part of me that wants to say yes. Certainly, the science we've seen since late summer, Bob, are encouraging. Some of the reports are coming out and data, both in terms of what the restaurants are seeing in terms of their volume and getting folks into their businesses as well as the sentiment. We're seeing the psychology tick up a little bit, and the optimism pick up ever so slightly, but everything helps here. So I think we are beginning to see some things that would hopefully lead to more positive growth for the industry. With that said, I think what we're also continuing to see is the strongest operators are doing the best as it is in our situation in the distribution side. So it's definitely better than it was a year ago, and we believe it's certainly better was maybe six months ago. I'd say it's still somewhat tenuous but if you're a good operator out there today, I think overall, you're starting to see some good signs.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

componenttext:
Good day, everyone. Welcome to the Syscos first quarter fiscal 2011 earnings results conference call. As a reminder, todays call is being recorded.
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, Id like to turn the call over to Neil Russell. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Syscos first quarter 2011 conference call. On todays call you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financia
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us for Syscos first quarter 2011 conference call. On todays call you will hear from Bill DeLaney, our President and Chief Executive Officer and Chris Kreidler, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made in the course of this presentation that state the companys or managements intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results could differ in a material manner.
Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ in a material manner from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the companys SEC filings, including but not limited to, risk factors contained in the companys Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended July 3, 2010 and in the companys press release issued earlier this morning.
On the call today we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. You can find the reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures on our Investor Relations Web site at sysco.com. Also, all comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted.
Lastly, we would like to remind that our Investor Day is scheduled for December 2. If you havent already registered, please do so prior to November 22.
With that out of the way, Ill turn the call over to our President and Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning Sysco reported net earnings of $299 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2011. Our sales in the first quarter increased 7.4%, driven mainly by increased case volume and estimated food cost inflation
componenttext:
Thanks Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning Sysco reported net earnings of $299 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2011. Our sales in the first quarter increased 7.4%, driven mainly by increased case volume and estimated food cost inflation of 3.3%.
Case volume was higher across all regions in our Broadline and SYGMA segments and the year-over-year increased represented the strongest improvement since the second quarter of fiscal 2007.
While the pace of the macroeconomic recovery remains sluggish and restaurant traffic patterns continue to be under pressure, recent data suggests the industry is slowly recovering. Syscos gradual but consistent improvement in case volume confirms this trend and we believe we are continuing to grow our market share.
We are pleased with our sales growth for the quarter and I should also note that we achieved record first quarter operating income. Nevertheless operating income growth over the prior year was less than our sales increase as improved expense management was more than offset by a 46 basis point decline in gross margin percent.
Several factors contributed to the decline in gross margins. Approximately 10 points of the margin decline related to a change in business mix. While both our Broadline and SYGMA businesses grew this quarter, SYGMA grew at a faster rate and since SYGMA operates a lower margin business, this mix shift impacted total margins.
We do not view this as a negative outcome. As a matter of fact, we see a great deal of opportunity on the contract side of the business, both from the Broadline and SYGMA segments. The key is to strike an appropriate balance between street and contract sales growth over time.
The remainder of the gross margin decline was split about evenly between two drivers. The first is a set of ongoing strategic pricing initiatives designed to drive volume increases in targeted categories.
While these initiatives are putting near-term pressure on our margins, we are starting to see double-digit volume increases where these programs have been effectively implemented. We expect this specific pressure on gross margins will persist in the near-term, but we also believe these initiatives will result in profitable market share gains over time.
The last component of the gross margin decline relates to the significant raise of inflation in the meat, dairy and sea food categories which together approached 10%. While we typically are able to pass through modest levels of price inflation on a timely basis, it is more difficult in the short-term to pass through double digit price increases to our customers without negatively impacting their business.
Our ongoing productivity initiatives helped to mitigate a portion of the gross margin pressure with U.S. Broadline warehouse cases per man hour and cases per trip increasing compared to last years first quarter. In addition, total sales per employee also increased year-over-year.
All that said, while operating performance in the first quarter is acceptable, its not up to our standards. We recently held our annual senior leadership meeting at which the importance of profitable sales growth was thoroughly discussed. Our management team understands that we must find ways to grow our earnings faster than sales during these challenging times.
Turning to our multi-year business transformation initiative for a moment, the project remains on track. We are preparing to begin the last of our four cycles of testing prior to go live with our pilot facility early next year.
Were also beginning to staff Sysco business services and have recently named Kirk Drummond to lead this strategically important part of our business. Kirk has been with Sysco for the last 24 years working in various capacities at our local operating companies and at corporate including five years as our Chief Information Officer and the last five years as our Senior Vice President and Treasurer.
This organization will centralize back office administrative functions such accounting, receivables, payables, billing and call center support.
Id like to close by thanking our associates and our management team for their ongoing contributions and commitment to Syscos success. This is an excitement time in our companys history and our associates continue to deliver a high level service and support to our customers.
While our business is facing certain challenges, we remain dedicated to being our customers most valued business partner and to investing in the future growth of Sysco. We know this focus strengthens our competitive position and provides the strong foundation for success over the long-term.
Now, Ill turn things over to Chris so he can provide additional details on our financial results for the quarter.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the first quarter, sales were $9.8 billion, or an increase of 7.4% compared to the prior year, driven mainly by case volume growth and the impact of food cost inflation which we estimate to be 3.3% for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. For the first quarter, sales were $9.8 billion, or an increase of 7.4% compared to the prior year, driven mainly by case volume growth and the impact of food cost inflation which we estimate to be 3.3% for the period.
In addition, acquisitions within the last 12 months increased sales by 0.6% and changes in foreign exchange rate increased sales by 0.5%.
Operating income increased $9 million or 1.8% to $506 million during the quarter. While sales increased 7.4%, gross margin increased only 4.8% and operating expense increased 6%.
Operating expense increased $75 million for the quarter due to three main drivers. First, salaries and related expense increased approximately $40 million, primarily from increased case volume during the quarter, including increased commissions and incentives and delivery personnel costs.
Total headcount was down very slightly compared to the prior year, meaning we held our headcount levels relatively steady despite increased case volume. While total headcount is down, weve increased MA headcount over the last year.
It typically takes one year to two years for an MA to be fully productive within the sales organization, but we consider this investment in the business to be an important one that will enhance our ability to grow sales as the industry recovers and continue to take market share.
Second, as we had discussed on last quarters call, pension expense increased by $15 million year-over-year. Lastly, operating expense included a $14 million benefit from the impact of Corporate Owned Life Insurance or COLI, which is an unfavorable comparison to the $21 million benefit we recorded in the prior year.
Net earnings for the first quarter were $299 million, declining $27 million or 8.3% compared to the prior year. Net earnings reflect a $39 million year-over-year increase in tax expense, primarily due to the IRS settlement gain and higher non-taxable COLI gains recorded in the prior year.
Excluding the impact of COLI in both periods and the IRS settlement gain, net earnings for the quarter as adjusted would have increased 3.4%. In addition the $15 million year-over-year increase in pension expense impacted net earnings by another 2.8 percentage points.
Earnings per share declined 7.3% to $0.51, which included a $0.02 benefit from COLI. In the prior year period, earnings per share were $0.55, and included a $0.05 gain related to the IRS settlement and a $0.04 benefit from COLI.
Turning to cash flow; cash flow from operations for the fiscal year was $227 million compared to $42 million in the prior year. Cash flow from operations increased year-over-year due mainly to the timing of our IRS settlement payments. During the first quarter of this year we had no settlement payments, however in the prior year period we paid $316 million.
We expect to pay a total of $212 million in settlement payments during this fiscal year and again next year. As a reminder, these scheduled payments include $106 million cash outflow in the second quarter period and a $53 million cash outflow in the third and fourth fiscal quarters.
Cash flow from operations was negatively impacted during the quarter by an increase in accounts receivable and a decline in accrued expense. Receivables increased due to higher sales during the period, and the decline in accrued expenses this quarter was due mainly to the payment of incentive compensation related to the prior fiscal year.
Capital expenditures totaled $143 million for the quarter including facility expansion and replacement, fleet replacements, and investments in technology including our business transformation project.
In closing, while the business environment remains challenging, were seeing improvements and our operating companies continue to have a strong focus on growing cases, controlling costs, improving productivity, and successfully implementing our business transformation. As a result, we are confident that Sysco is well positioned to take advantage of the economic recovery as it takes hold.
With that operator, we will now take questions.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) And well take our first question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) And well take our first question from Ajay Jain with Hapoalim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. I just wanted to clarify a few things on the gross margin impact during the quarter. I think some of that decline I am sure is a little bit cosmetic because of the inflation impact And Bill, I think you already talked about the mix shift
componenttext: Hi, good morning. I just wanted to clarify a few things on the gross margin impact during the quarter. I think some of that decline I am sure is a little bit cosmetic because of the inflation impact And Bill, I think you already talked about the mix shift between SYGMA and Broadline, but as far as the strategic price investments that I think you cited in your press release, it seems at least to me a little bit unprecedented for Sysco to have to resort to discounting based on the way you guys have typically gone to market. So can you just talk about how far reaching these price investments are going to be over the rest of the year, and if you had to quantify how much of the 46 basis point decline was driven by price investments in this last quarter, is that something that you can quantify at all?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ive given my best shot, and well see where we end up here. So to repeat, of the 46 basis point decline we think about 10 basis point of that is the business mix of SYGMA versus the Broadline. So that leaves you a little over a third of a point of ma
componenttext:
Ive given my best shot, and well see where we end up here. So to repeat, of the 46 basis point decline we think about 10 basis point of that is the business mix of SYGMA versus the Broadline. So that leaves you a little over a third of a point of margin decline. Our best estimate is about half of that is we would attribute to pretty significant inflation in those three categories. I mentioned meat, dairy and seafood, and the other half I dont know Id call discounting or pricing so much as what we would characterize is as what we said is strategic category initiatives.
Where we see opportunities, Ajay, where we are somewhat underpenetrated and we think its appropriate for us to get a little more focused and get a little more finely priced in those categories. So weve been into this year for a few months and I would expect that to continue here over a good portion of the balance of the year, but its not a random type of thing. Its distinct categories and were doing it in different parts of the country and over time throughout the country, and again, I would expect us to maybe not in 12 months, but over a reasonable period of time see it pay back there on the sales line.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: So going forward, would the gross margin implications from these category management initiatives, with the magnitude be similar to this latest quarter?
componenttext: So going forward, would the gross margin implications from these category management initiatives, with the magnitude be similar to this latest quarter?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its actually hard to predict. I mean, theres a lot of things that go in the gross margin, Ajay, but I would say, for this piece of the pie so to speak, I think as we said and I think as I said in the narrative, I expect the pressure to continue here
componenttext: Its actually hard to predict. I mean, theres a lot of things that go in the gross margin, Ajay, but I would say, for this piece of the pie so to speak, I think as we said and I think as I said in the narrative, I expect the pressure to continue here for at least a couple more quarters. With that said, I think theres other things we can manage better including the inflation part and thats what we were alluding to in terms of our discussions with our management team. There is opportunities for us to manage this inflation environment somewhat better.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just this one quick follow-up on the tax rate, I know theres some variability each quarter based on stock compensation and COLI, but could you talk about what youre assuming as far as a normalized tax rate for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Just this one quick follow-up on the tax rate, I know theres some variability each quarter based on stock compensation and COLI, but could you talk about what youre assuming as far as a normalized tax rate for the rest of the year?

componenttext: Obviously, a normalized rate for Sysco is probably 38%, 39%. Whats going on with the tax rate is primarily driven by the IRS settlement last year and the COLI, both last year and this year. Those are the two main drivers thats affecting the tax rate.

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010

componenttext: But as far as what youre modeling in internally, is 38% to 39% representative of what we should be assuming as well?

headline: Sysco Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 08, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thats a normalized tax rate. Im not really commenting about what we expect for the year, to be candid. We dont really know what COLI is going to be for the full year. We start the year off assuming COLI is going to be flat. Obviously, it wa
componenttext: Well, thats a normalized tax rate. Im not really commenting about what we expect for the year, to be candid. We dont really know what COLI is going to be for the full year. We start the year off assuming COLI is going to be flat. Obviously, it wasnt flat in this first quarter. We got a benefit from it. We dont really know whats going to happen for the duration of the year. So I would say, yes, we started the year assuming 38% to 39%. We knew that we were going to have a lapping issue in the first quarter because of the things that happened in the first quarter last year.
